questions.text: A patient with leprosy presented with the deformity as shown below. Which nerve injury causes the given condition ?
questions.solution:
The given image shows extension at the metacarpophalangeal joint and flexion at interphalangeal joints of the ring and little finger, caused by ulnar nerve injury. It produces a claw hand (main en griffe). Leprosy can affect peripheral nerves and lead to their associated conditions.

In ulnar nerve palsy, only the medial two fingers develop clawing, while in a combined median and ulnar nerve palsy, all four fingers develop clawing. 

The ulnar nerve supplies the medial two lumbricals in the hand. The lumbricals have a combined action on metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joint flexion and interphalangeal (IP) joint extension (glass holding posture). In ulnar nerve injury, since the medial lumbricals are not functional, the forearm muscles are unopposed. Hence, there is hyperextension at MCP joints and flexion at IP joints. This causes claw hand deformity. There is also numbness of the ulnar one and a half fingers. 

Elbow fractures or dislocations lead to high lesions of the ulnar nerve. Here, the hand is not markedly deformed because the ulnar half of the flexor digitorum profundus is paralyzed and the fingers, therefore, appear less clawed. This is called the high ulnar paradox.

The following tests are done to test the integrity of the ulnar nerve:

  • Egawa's test - In a positive test, due to the weakness of the dorsal interossei, side-to-side movements of the middle finger is weak.
  • Book test or Froment's sign - The patient is asked to hold a book forcefully while the doctor tries to pull it. In a positive test, due to weakness of adductor pollicis muscle, adduction of thumb is lost. The patient tries to hold the book by using flexor pollicis longus muscle. This produces flexion at the inter-phalangeal joint while holding the book.
  • Card test - In the case of weak palmar interossei, it is easy for the examiner to pull out the card when held between the fingers. This is due to the loss of adduction by palmar interossei muscles.

Other options

Option B - In radial nerve palsy, the patient presents with 'wrist drop' in case of paralyzed wrist extensors, and 'finger drop' when extensor digitorum is paralyzed. When there is compression in the axilla, radial nerve palsy is called Saturday night palsy. There is paralysis of the triceps, and weakness of the wrist and hand. In high lesions, there is sensory loss on the dorsum of the hand over the anatomical stuff box. 

Option C - In median nerve injury, paralysis of opponens pollicis muscle leads to 'ape thumb' deformity. In forearm or elbow injuries, there is paralysis of long flexors of the thumb, index, and middle fingers, radial wrist flexors, and forearm pronators. This leads to the characteristic 'pointing index finger'. There is sensory loss over three and a half digits on the radial side. 

Option D -Posterior interosseous nerve injury, is seen in posterior interosseous syndrome. The wrist is in radial deviation and there is loss of metacarpophalangeal joint extension. However, wrist extension is preserved.

questions.text: Identify the tarsal bone labelled in the image below.
questions.solution:
The image shows the navicular bone which is interposed between the head of the talus and the cuneiforms.

There are 7 tarsal bones and they occupy the proximal half of foot. The proximal row is made up of the talus and calcaneum. The distal row from medial to lateral contains, the medial, intermediate, and lateral cuneiforms and the cuboid. Medially the navicular bone is interposed between the head of the talus and the cuneiforms.

questions.text: What type of joint is seen at the labelled structure?
questions.solution:
Pubic Symphysis is a secondary cartilaginous joint.

Structurally, joints are classified as fibrous joints, cartilaginous joints, and synovial joints (see the table). Sutures, syndesmosis, and gomphosis are fibrous joints. Symphysis and synchondrosis are types of cartilaginous joints.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked as 'C'.
questions.solution:
The structure marked as 'C', is the Epiglottis.

The structures marked in the image are:

  1. Hyoid bone
  2. Thyroid cartilage
  3. Epiglottis
  4. Cricoid cartilage

The laryngeal skeleton is formed by a series of cartilages that are connected by ligaments and fibrous membranes:

  • The thyroid, cricoid, and the greater part of the arytenoid cartilages consist of hyaline cartilage.
  • The corniculate, cuneiform, tritiate, and epiglottic cartilages and the apices of the arytenoid cartilage consist of elastic cartilage.
  • The hyoid bone is a 'U-shaped' bone suspended from the tips of the styloid processes by the stylohyoid ligaments.

questions.text: What is the embryological basis of the developmental defect shown in the image below?

choices.text: Failure in closure of anterior neuropore of neural tube
Failure in closure of posterior neuropore of neural tube
Failure in closure of complete neural tube
Failure in closure of caudal neuropore of neural tube

questions.solution:
The image shows anencephaly.

Failure of the anterior end (cranial end) of the neural tube to close is known as exencephaly. As a result of this, the skull vault does not form. This leaves the malformed brain exposed. The exposed brain tissue degenerates, leaving a mass of necrotic tissue. This defect with the absence of a major portion of the brain, skull, and scalp is known as anencephaly. The brain stem remains intact.

In some cases, the closure defect of the neural tube extends caudally, and the spinal cord is affected. This condition is known as craniorachischisis, where there is anencephaly plus a large defect involving the spine. 

Neurulation refers to the formation of the neural tube from the neural plate. The neural tube gives rise to the central nervous system. 

Steps of neurulation

  • The notochord induces the overlying ectoderm to thicken and form the neural plate.
  • The neural plate lengthens and the lateral edges elevate to form the neural folds, and the mid-region gets depressed to form the neural groove.
  • The neural folds approach each and fuse in the midline in a craniocaudal direction to form a tube-like structure called the neural tube.
  • The anterior opening of the neural tube (cranial neuropore) closes by day 25 and the posterior opening (caudal neuropore) closes by day 28.
  • The neural tube becomes the central nervous system.

questions.text: A newborn presented to the NICU with respiratory distress and meconium discharge from the umbilicus. The condition occurs due to the patency of the which structure?
questions.solution:
The presence of meconium discharge at the umbilicus is suggestive of vitelline fistula, which occurs due to patent vitelline duct, which connects the primitive gut to the yolk sac.

The primitive gut is connected to the definitive yolk sac through a narrow stalk-like communication known as the vitellointestinal duct. It is also known as vitelline duct or yolk stalk or omphalomesenteric duct. 

Due to the folding of the embryo in the cephalocaudal and lateral directions, the embryo gets enclosed all around by ectoderm, except in the region through which the vitellointestinal duct passes. In this region, there is a circular aperture, which is now called the umbilical opening. The vitellointestinal duct completely obliterates by the 7th week of development.

Vitelline duct abnormalities:

  • Meckel's diverticulum: In about 2% of the individuals, a portion of the vitelline duct persists an outpouching of the ileum called, Meckel diverticulum. The diverticulum is usually asymptomatic unless it contains heterotopic pancreatic or gastric mucosa, which may lead to bleeding, ulceration, or perforation.
  • Vitelline cyst: In some individuals, both the ends of the vitelline duct transform into fibrous cords. However, the middle portion of the duct forms a large cyst called, enterocystoma, or vitelline cyst. As the fibrous cords run across the peritoneal cavity, it may lead to intestinal obstruction, strangulation, or volvulus.
  • Vitelline fistula: When the vitelline duct remains patent over its entire length, it forms a direct communication between the primitive gut and the umbilicus, a condition called an umbilical fistula or vitelline fistula. The newborn characteristically presents with meconium discharge from the umbilicus.

questions.text: Which artery is being palpated in the image shown below?
questions.solution:
The posterior tibial artery is palpated between the medial malleolus and the calcaneal tendon, as shown in the image.

The posterior tibial artery can be felt by keeping the foot relaxed between plantar and dorsiflexion and palpating against the distal tibia behind and below the medial malleolus,approximately one-third of a line connecting the posterior border of the medial malleolus to the calcaneal tendon(Achilles tendon)

Other options:

Dorsalis pedis artery: 

  • palpated against the underlying tarsals
  • lateral to the tendon of extensor hallucis longus from the midpoint between the malleoli to the proximal end of the first intermetatarsal space. 

Popliteal artery: 

  • most difficult of the peripheral pulses to feel because the artery lies deep in the popliteal fossa.
  • examined with the subject lying supine or prone, with the knee flexed in order to relax the tense popliteal fascia that roofs the popliteal fossa.
  • felt over the midline of the fossa by deep pressure against the popliteal surface of the femur.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the diagram showing the development of ovarian follicles.
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the image is of a secondary follicle, also called an antral follicle.

Development of ovarian follicles: 

At birth, the ovarian cortex contains numerous primordial follicles which contain primary oocytes surrounded by a single layer of flat follicular cells. Most of these follicles degenerate in the prepubertal life and are called atretic follicles. At puberty, around 20 primordial follicles get activated in each menstrual cycle. Out of these 20 primordial follicles, only one follicle is dominant which reaches maturity and releases the oocyte during ovulation. 

The different stages of development of the primordial follicle are: 

a) Primary follicle:

  • Follicle cells change from flattened cells to cuboidal and the stromal cells surrounding the follicle differentiate into spindle-shaped cells called 'theca externa'.
  • The oocyte increases in size and secretes a proteoglycan material around it which forms the layer called 'Zona Pellucida' which is seen between the plasma membrane of the oocyte and the granulosa cells. 

b)Secondary follicle(Antral follicle):

  • The primary follicles continue to increase in size and the granulosa cells multiply.
  • Numerous cavities coalesce to form a single fluid space called antrum.
  • The granulosa cells envelop the oocyte to form a structure called Cumulus oophorus.

c) Tertiary follicle (Graffian follicle):

  • Numerous secondary follicles are formed but only one tertiary follicle develops while others regress and become atretic follicles.
  • As the antrum draws the fhe follicle increase in size and expands to a diameter of 2 cm to become Graffian follicle.
  • The oocyte and the surrounding granulosa cells called corona radiata break away from the follicular wall and float in the follicular fluid.
  • The primary oocyte completes its first meiotic division to form the secondary oocyte and a polar body.
  • The secondary oocyte is arrested in the metaphase of the second meiotic division until fertilization takes place.
  • The follicle ruptures to release the oocyte which is captured by for the fimbriae.

d) Corpus Luteum:

  • The remainder of the follicle after ovulation is called the Corpus luteum. It synthesizes a carotenoid pigment called lutein which gives it a yellowish colour.
  • If the oocyte is not fertilized then corpus luteum degenerates 12-14 days after ovulation to become corpus albicans.
  • If fertilization occurs then the hCG produced by the trophoblast maintains the corpus luteum. It releases progesterone, estrogen, and relaxin, and regresses at around 8 weeks when the placenta takes over.

questions.text: Match the auscultatory areas of the heart from image given below
questions.solution:
The image shows the auscultation areas of the heart and option B is correctly matched. 

The auscultation areas correspond to the areas where the sounds and murmurs of the heart valves can be best heard. 

  • Mitral area- At the apex of the heart which is at the 5th Intercostal space in the midclavicular line. 
  • Tricuspid area- Lower left sternal edge in the left 4th intercoastal space.
  • Pulmonic area-Upper left sternal edge in the left 2nd intercoastal space
  • Aortic area- Upper right sternal edge in the right 2nd intercoastal space. 

An image showing the auscultation areas of the heart is shown below:

 

The routine auscultation of the heart is:

  • Auscultate at the apex with the diaphragm.
  • Turn the patient on to the left side and auscultate for any murmurs of MR(using diaphragm) or MS(using bell)
  • Turn the patient to the supine position, recline at 45 degrees and auscultate at the tricuspid area for murmurs of TR, TS, VSD
  • Auscultate at the pulmonic area (PS,PR, PDA)
  • Auscultate at the aortic area (AS, HOCM)
  • Sit the patient forward and auscultate again at the tricuspid area in held expiration(AR)
  • Auscultate over the carotid arteries for any bruits or radiation of any murmurs.

questions.text: The image below shows the cross-section of the trachea. Identify the structure marked.
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the image shows the trachealis muscle. 

The trachea is a tube-like structure that allows air to pass between the larynx and the bronchi.

The trachealis muscle is a smooth muscle located at the posterior wall of the trachea. It connects the ends of the C-shaped tracheal cartilage rings and completes the posterior part of the tracheal wall.

The histological section of the trachea shows the following structures:

  • Respiratory epithelium
  • Basement membrane
  • Submucosal glands (both serous and mucous parts)
  • Perichondrium
  • Tracheal cartilage
  • Trachealis muscle (smooth muscle).

The histological image below is that of the trachea as identified by the presence of pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium lining, the serous and mucous glands, and hyaline cartilage.

questions.text: The vertical plane that divides the body into anterior and posterior parts is known as __________.
questions.solution:
The coronal plane is a vertical that divides the body into anterior and posterior parts. 

Four imaginary planes are used in anatomical descriptions:

  • Median (mid-sagittal) plane: Vertical plane that divides the body into equal right and left halves  
  • Sagittal plane: Vertical plane that divides the body into unequal right and left parts; parallel to the median plane
  • Coronal (frontal) plane: Vertical plane that divides the body into anterior and posterior parts; perpendicular to the median plane
  • Transverse (horizontal) plane: Horizontal plane that divides the body into upper and lower parts; perpendicular to both the sagittal and coronal planes

Note: Axial (or trans-axial) plane is a term used in radiology for the horizontal plane.

questions.text: The  fallopian tube is lined by ______.
questions.solution:
The lining epithelium of the fallopian tube is a single layer of ciliated columnar epithelium. 

The ciliated epithelial cells are predominant in the distal part of the fallopian tube. There is an increase in the height and number of cilia in these cells during the estrogenic phase of the menstrual cycle.

Other cells in the fallopian tube epithelium include:

  • Secretory or peg cells - maximally located in the proximal portion of the tube. These cells are active around the time of ovulation, and their secretions help in the capacitation of sperms.
  • Intraepithelial lymphocytes - may present occasionally. 

 

Related Pearl: Fallopian tube

Gross anatomy:

The fallopian tube is divided into the following parts:

  • Intramural/Interstitial portion:  
    • Intrauterine
    • The narrowest and shortest part
  • Isthmus:
    • The most common site for tubectomy
  • Ampulla:
    • The longest part
    • The most common site for - fertilization and ectopic pregnancy
  • Infundibulum:
    • The widest part

Histology:

The ampulla, isthmus and infundibulum are extrauterine. They're covered by three layers: 

  • Mesosalpinx - It is the peritoneal layer. Also called serosa.
  • Myosalpinx - It contains smooth muscle and has 2 layers:
    • Inner circular 
    • Outer longitudinal
  • Endosalpinx - It is the mucosal layer. It has the following features:
    • Numerous branching folds, filling the entire lumen
    • Basement membrane
    • Ciliated, columnar epithelium 
    • Peg cells - non-ciliated epithelium. They help in the capacitation of sperms. 

Related Pearl: Various Types of Epithelium, Their Location and Functions

questions.text: At what level does the spinal cord end in infants?
questions.solution:
In infants, the spinal cord ends at the L3 level.

As the child grows, the spinal cord moves up with age. Thus in adults, the distal termination of the spinal cord is at the lower border of L1.

The nerve roots from the lower end of the spinal cord form the cauda equina which exit through the intervertebral foramina. These fibers float in the dural sac and tend to be pushed away when a needle is advanced as in spinal anesthesia.

Thus spinal anesthesia is administered in adults below the lower border of L1 and in children below the lower border of L3, to minimize the chances of injury to the spinal cord

questions.text: The neurovascular plane of the abdominal wall lies_______.

choices.text: Between the internal oblique and external oblique
Between the internal oblique and rectus abdominis
Between the internal oblique and transversus abdominis

questions.solution:
The neurovascular plane of the abdominal wall lies between the internal oblique and transversus abdominis in the anterior abdominal wall.

The plane contains:

  • Lower 6 thoracic nerves (T7-12)
  • Iliohypogastric nerves
  • Posterior intercostal and subcostal vessels
  • Anastomosis between superior and inferior epigastric arteries.

questions.text: Given below is a histological section of the thyroid gland. Which of the following is secreted by the cell marked 'X' in the image?
questions.solution:
The structure marked X is the C-cells or the parafollicular cells of the thyroid gland and they secrete calcitonin.

The C-cells (clear cells or parafollicular cells) have a pale staining cytoplasm, they are present between the follicular cells and the basement membrane or between the follicles. They are usually found in the middle third of each lateral lobe of the thyroid and scattered in between the thyroid follicles. They are members of the APUD system of dispersed neuroendocrine cells. They secrete calcitonin which lowers blood calcium.

The thyroid gland is covered by a fibrous capsule with septae dividing it into lobules. These lobules contain follicles lined by follicular cells. The shape of the follicular cells depends on the activity of the gland. They're squamous in the inactive state, cuboidal to columnar in the active state. The cavity of the follicle contains colloid which appears pink in H and E staining.

questions.text: The structure used to demarcate upper gastrointestinal bleeding and lower gastrointestinal bleeding is _________.
questions.solution:
The ligament of Treitz is part of the duodenojejunal junction and forms the line of demarcation for gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding.

Upper GI bleeding refers to bleeding proximal to the ligament of Treitz, and lower GI bleeding refers to bleeding distal to the ligament of Treitz.

questions.text: A patient presents with symptoms as shown in the image below: 1) shows the site of the lesion,  2) has loss of proprioception, vibration, and discriminative touch on the same side, and 3) has loss of pain and temperature beginning one or two segments below the side of the lesion on the contralateral side. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image along with the features above is diagnostic of Brown Sequard syndrome.

Hemisection of the spinal cord causes damage to ascending sensory (dorsal column pathway, ventrolateral spinothalamic tract) and descending motor (corticospinal tract) pathways, which is called the Brown-Séquard syndrome.

The part marked as 1 is the site of the lesion, at which hemisection of the cord is seen.

The part marked as 2 is the ipsilateral side of the lesion, which has the following features:

  • Loss of proprioception and vibration
  • Loss of discriminative touch
  • Weakness and spastic type of paralysis in certain muscle groups

The part marked as 3 is the contralateral side of the lesion and exhibits the following features:

  • Loss of pain and temperature beginning one or two segments below the side of the lesion

Related Pearl: Brown Sequard syndrome (Hemisection of spinal cord)

questions.text: Which of the following cell organelles is associated with killing bacteria and viruses?
questions.solution:
Lysosomes contain hydrolytic enzymes and are associated with killing bacteria and viruses. 

Lysosomes  are membrane-bound organelles broken off from the Golgi apparatus, containing roughly 40 different acid hydrolases (enzymes that function best in acidic pH ≤5). These hydrolases include proteases, nucleases, lipases, glycosidases, phosphatases, and sulfatases.

Lysosomal enzymes provide an intracellular digestive system that digests damaged cellular structures, food particles ingested by the cells, and foreign particles like bacteria and viruses. The membrane around the lysosomes prevents the hydrolytic enzymes from being in contact with the other substances in the cell and prevents them from being digested. 

When an enzyme is congenitally absent, the cell becomes engorged with the material the enzyme normally degrades. This leads to lysosomal diseases e.g Gaucher disease is caused due to a deficiency of glucocerebrosidase.

questions.text: Following complete ileal and partial jejunal resection, the patient is most likely to have
questions.solution:
After complete ileal and partial jejunal resection, the patient is likely to have vitamin B12 deficiency.

Vitamin B12 is absorbed in the ileum. B12 binds to intrinsic factor, a protein secreted by the parietal cells of the stomach, and the complex is absorbed across the ileal mucosa. Hence after ileal resection, there is impaired absorption of vitamin B12.

Clinical features of megaloblastic anemia (cyanocobalamin and folate deficiency):

System Clinical features
Oral

Glossitis

Angular cheilosis
Gastrointestinal

Anorexia

Weight loss

Diarrhea

Constipation
Skin Hyperpigmentation (reversible)
Hematological

Thrombocytopenia

Leucopenia

Ineffective erythropoiesis and unconjugated jaundice
Cardiovascular

Atherosclerosis leading to PVD, CAD (due to elevated homocysteine)
Neurological (only B12)

Peripheral neuropathy

Subacute combined degeneration (degeneration of the posterior and pyramidal tracts of the spinal cord)
Pregnancy (only folate)

Recurrent fetal loss

Neural tube defects
Others

Mild fever in severe cases

Psychiatric disturbances

Peripheral smear findings:

  • Macro-ovalocytes are seen.
  • Most macrocytes lack the central pallor of normal red cells and even appear hyperchromic, but the MCHC is not elevated.
  • Reticulocyte count is low.
  • Nucleated red cell progenitors occasionally appear in the circulating blood when anemia is severe.
  • Neutrophils are also larger than normal (macro polymorphonuclear) and show nuclear hypersegmentation, with five or more nuclear lobules.

Bone marrow findings:

  • Markedly hypercellular as a result of increased hematopoietic precursors
  • Sieve-like pattern of chromatin of immature precursors (Megaloblasts)
  • Granulocytic precursors display dysmaturation in the form of giant metamyelocytes and band forms
  • Megakaryocytes abnormally large and have bizarre, multilobate nuclei
  • Derangement in DNA synthesis causes most precursors to undergo apoptosis in the marrow (ineffective hematopoiesis) and leads to pancytopenia

Related Pearl: Major Sites of Absorption of Hematopoietic Factors

  • Duodenum + upper jejunum: Iron
  • Jejunum: Folate
  • Terminal Ileum: Vitamin B12

Mnemonic - Dude Is Just Feeling Ill Bro

questions.text: A mother complains of cramps in her breasts while breastfeeding her child. Which hormone is responsible for this?
questions.solution:
Oxytocin helps in the ejection of milk by myoepithelial contraction. This may result in cramps in the breast tissue.

     Functions of oxytocin are:

  • Milk ejection (Myoepithelial contraction)
  • ADH like action in high doses (reduces urine output)
  • Uterine contraction

Estrogen (Ductal growth)

Progesterone (Alveolar growth)

questions.text: Which of the following conditions will shift the Oxygen-Hb dissociation curve to the left?
questions.solution:
An increase in the pH (alkalosis), shifts the O2-hemoglobin dissociation curve, to the left.

Oxygen-Hb dissociation curve (OHDC)

  • This is a plot of the partial pressure of O2 and the % saturation of Hb with O2.
  • It is normally sigmoid in shape.
  • If OHDC is shifted to the right, it means that the affinity of Hb for O2 has become less (which favors O2 delivery) i.e. Higher the P50. (R - Right shift Releases oxygen)

Shift to the right is caused by: (Conditions with an increased requirement of O2 - metabolically active tissues)

  • Hypoxia and Hypercarbia - Metabolically active tissues utilize O2 and tissues produce CO2
  • ↓ pH - Secondary to increased CO2 production
  • ↑ in temperature, heat 
  • ↑ in 2,3-DPG - increased anaerobic glycolysis
  • Growth hormone, thyroid hormone, androgen - by increasing 2,3 DPG
  • Sickle cell anemia - reduced affinity for O2

Shift to the left is caused by:

  • ↑ pH (alkalosis)
  • ↓ PCO2
  • ↓ 2,3-DPG
  • ↓ Temperature 
  • HbF
  • Carboxyhemoglobin

questions.text: Phases of the ventricular muscle action potential are shown below. At which phase is the action potential most dependent on sodium permeability?
questions.solution:
The action potential is most dependant on sodium permeability in phase 0. 

Action potential of myocardium:

  • Phase 0: Depolarisation: Influx of Na+ into myocyte.
  • Phase 1: Early repolarization: Efflux of K+ from myocyte.
  • Phase 2: Plateau: Ca2+ enters myocardial cells via voltage regulated L-type Ca2+ channels.
  • Phase 3: Repolarisation: Efflux of K+.
  • Phase 4: Restoration of RMP: Restoration of Na+ and K+ by Na-K ATPase.

questions.text: The neurotransmitter released by the Renshaw cell is?
questions.solution:
The neurotransmitter released by the Renshaw cell is glycine.

Renshaw cell inhibition is an example of negative feedback inhibition. The axon of a spinal motor neuron gives a recurrent collateral that synapses on an inhibitory interneuron that terminates on the cell body of the same and other motor neurons. This inhibitory interneuron is called a Renshaw cell and its neurotransmitter is glycine.

The Renshaw cell releases glycine to reduce the activity of the motor neuron.

questions.text: The following principle-' In spinal cords, dorsal roots are sensory and ventral roots are motor' is known as ______
questions.solution:
The principle that in the spinal cord the dorsal roots are sensory and the ventral roots are motor is known as the Bell–Magendie law.

Laws in Sensory Physiology

  • Muller's doctrine of specific nerve energies: When the nerve pathways from a particular sense organ are stimulated, the sensation evoked is that for which the receptor is specialized, no matter how or where along the pathway the activity is initiated.
  • Law of projection: No matter where a particular sensory pathway is stimulated along its course to the cortex, the conscious sensation produced is referred to the location of the receptor.
  • Weber-Fechner Law: Magnitude of sensation felt is directly proportional to the log of the intensity of the stimulus.
  • Labelled line theory: All the sensations from the different parts of the body travel along specified paths. For example, in the posterior column, fibers from the lower parts of the body are placed medially.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy living near the sea mistakenly consumes pufferfish and complains of vomiting, diarrhoea, abdominal pain with ascending paralysis, and eventually dies with respiratory failure. The toxin in this poisoning acts mainly on which of the following channels?
questions.solution:
Puffer fish poisoning is caused by the toxin tetrodotoxin. This toxin acts mainly on the sodium channnels.

This toxin is also used to study the flow of ions across the various other individual channels by blocking sodium channels. For instance, the sodium channels are blocked by tetrodotoxin when it is applied to the outside of the cell membrane where the sodium activation gates are located.

questions.text: Which of the following events cannot be seen in a normal ECG?
questions.solution:
Atrial repolarization cannot be seen on a normal ECG.

Atrial repolarization occurs during the ventricular depolarization. However, the voltage of the atrial repolarization is very low and is masked by the QRS complex representing ventricular depolarization.

questions.text: Which of the following cells is involved in the initiation and control of osteoclastic activity?
questions.solution:
Osteoblasts are involved in the initiation and control of osteoclastic activity. 

Osteoblasts produce receptor activator for nuclear factor κ­B ligand (RANKL) and macrophage colony­ stimulating factor (M-CSF), which are necessary for formation of mature osteoclasts and hence osteoclastic activity. 

Specific receptors for parathormone are present only on the osteoblasts and not on osteoclasts.

questions.text: ACTH secretion is inhibited by______
questions.solution: Glucocorticoids inhibit ACTH secretion by a direct negative feedback mechanism. They also inhibit CRH secretion.

questions.text: In fetus, the insulin secretion begins by _____(months)
questions.solution:
In a fetus, the pancreatic islets are formed in the third month of the fetal life, while insulin secretion begins at about 5th month of fetal life.

The exocrine pancreas starts functioning after birth.

questions.text: How long is thyroxine stored in thyroid follicles?
questions.solution:
Thyroxine is stored in the thyroid follicles for 2-3 months, bound to thyroglobulin. 

When the synthesis of thyroid hormone ceases, the physiological effects of deficiency are not observed for several months.

questions.solution:
The given image shows glucose transporter that transports glucose from a higher concentration to lower concentration. This is an example of facilitated diffusion.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in strenuous exercise?

choices.text: Right shift of O2-Hb dissociation curve

questions.solution:
Strenuous exercise can cause hyperkalemia by releasing potassium from skeletal muscle.

NOTE: Exercise leads to release of endogenous opiods and is associated with mood enhancement.

questions.text: Inhibin B is secreted by______
questions.solution:
The inhibins are produced by the granulosa cells of the follicle, as well as other tissues, including the pituitary, the brain, the adrenal gland, the kidney, the bone marrow, the corpus luteum, and the placenta. Inhibin A is produced by corpus luteum whereas inhibin B is mainly prduced by granulosa cells of the follicle

FSH specifically stimulates the granulosa cells to produce inhibins.

Just before ovulation, after the granulosa cells acquire LH receptors, LH also stimulates the production of inhibin by granulosa cells.

questions.text: Which of the following steps in the metabolism of Vitamin D requires sunlight?
questions.solution:
In the metabolism of vitamin D, the conversion of 7-dehydrocholesterol to cholecalciferol requires sunlight.

Vitamin D metabolism occurs in 3 steps:

Step 1- Skin: 7-dehydrocholesterol (an intermediate in cholesterol synthesis that accumulates in the skin) undergoes a nonenzymic reaction on exposure to ultraviolet light, yielding cholecalciferol, which is absorbed into the bloodstream. Note that 7-Dehydrocholesterol and cholecalciferol already contain one hydroxy group.

Step 2- Liver:  Cholecalciferol is hydroxylated to 25-hydroxycholecalciferol. This is released into the circulation bound to a vitamin D–binding globulin, which is the main storage form of the vitamin.

Step 3- Kidney: 25-hydroxycholecalciferol is converted to 1,25 dihydroxycholecalciferol, the biologically active form by the enzyme 1α-hydroxylase.

questions.text: Menke’s disease is due to a deficiency of ___.
questions.solution:
Menke’s disease is due to a deficiency of copper. 

It is an X‐linked recessive disorder caused by a mutation in ATP7A, which encodes for a copper-transporting ATPase‐α polypeptide.

Related Pearl: Menkes disease

questions.text: Classical galactosemia is due to a deficiency of which enzyme?
questions.solution:
Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase deficiency leads to classical galactosemia. It is an autosomal recessive disorder.

Clinical features :

  • Accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate in the liver causes liver damage & leads to hepatomegaly, vomiting, convulsions.
  • Accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate depletes the liver of inorganic phosphate leading to diminished ATP synthesis which affects gluconeogenesis resulting in hypoglycemia.
  • Accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate in the nerves causes intellectual disability.
  • Accumulation of galactitol in the lens causes oil-drop cataract.

Urinary reducing sugar (Benedict's test) and Mucic acid test is positive.

Treatment is galactose-free diet.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a function of glucagon?
questions.solution:
Glycolysis is not a function of glucagon but is a function of insulin. 

Role of insulin and glucagon:

When blood glucose falls during fasting, there is increased secretion of glucagon and decreased release of insulin.

Effects of increased glucagon: insulin ratio on enzymes of glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis:

  1. It activates glycogen phosphorylase, the key enzyme of glycogenolysis, and deactivates glycogen synthase. This causes a rapid mobilization of liver glycogen stores to be utilized as fuel.
  2. It favors the synthesis of glucose-6-phosphatase which converts glucose-6-phosphate to glucose. The resulting glucose is used by red blood cells (lack mitochondria) and the brain as they are largely dependent on glucose in the fasting state.
  3. Phosphoenol pyruvate carboxykinase and fructose-1, 6-bisphosphatase are induced, leading to increased gluconeogenesis.

Gluconeogenesis    Increased                Decreased            
Glycogenolysis  Increased                Decreased
Ketogenesis  Increased                Decreased
Glycogen storage  Decreased  Increased

questions.text: A 34-year-old male, who had been consuming maize as a primary staple food for an extended period, presented with glossitis and a pigmented rash in areas exposed to the sun. Additionally, a lesion was observed on his neck, as depicted in the image provided. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical secnario and image finding showing casal's necklace is suggestive of pellagra. It is caused due to niacin deficiency.

Niacin is a nutrient that is synthesized in the body from tryptophan. The term niacin represents two compounds nicotinic acid and nicotinamide. It acts as a precursor for the coenzymes NAD and NADP, which are important in various oxidation and reduction reactions.

Niacin deficiency causes pellagra. It is usually seen in individuals with a corn/ maize-based staple diet, a history of alcohol consumption, hartnup disease, and carcinoid syndrome. 

The primary manifestations of pellagra are often referred to as the 4D's as follows, diarrhea, dermatitis, dementia, leading to death. Other manifestations include, abdominal pain, loss of appetite, bright red glossitis, generalized weakness, irritability, casal’s necklace(pigmented scaly skin rash around the neck).

It is diagnosed by measuring urinary levels of 2-methyl nicotinamide and 2-pyridone. Treatment is oral supplementation of 100–200 mg of nicotinamide or nicotinic acid three times daily for 5 days.

Other options :

Option B : Scurvy is caused due to vitamin c deficiency. It is associated with symptoms like bleeding gums, bruising, joint pain, and fatigue. Scurvy is not associated with a rash like the one described, nor does it typically cause cognitive dysfunction or diarrhea. Hence, high-dose vitamin C would not improve this patient’s symptoms.

Option C : Megaloblastic anemia is an RBC disorder caused by a deficiency of Vitamin B12 or folic acid. This deficiency results in impaired DNA synthesis, leading to ineffective hematopoiesis and distinctive morphologic changes, including abnormally large erythroid precursors and red cells.

Option D : Beri beri is caused due to thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency. It is characterized by symptoms such as muscle weakness, peripheral neuropathy, cardiovascular issues, and confusion.

questions.text: Cholesterol is synthesized primarily from___.
questions.solution:
Cholesterol is synthesized from acetyl-CoA mainly in the liver, adrenal cortex, testes, ovaries, and intestine.

The enzymes involved in cholesterol synthesis are partly located in the endoplasmic reticulum and partly in the cytoplasm. The enzyme HMG CoA reductase is the principal enzyme involved in the regulation of cholesterol synthesis in the body.

HMG-CoA is reduced to mevalonate by NADPH in a reaction catalyzed by HMG-CoA reductase which is the principal regulatory step in the pathway of cholesterol synthesis. It is the site of action of the cholesterol-lowering statins, which are HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors.

Long-term regulation of cholesterol synthesis involves regulating the transcription of the gene for HMG CoA reductase. When there is sufficient cholesterol in the cell, transcription of the gene for HMG CoA reductase is suppressed, and there is decreased synthesis of cholesterol. 

Cholesterol regulates the expression of the gene for HMG CoA reductase. When cholesterol is less, proteases in the Golgi bodies cleave a sterol regulatory element-binding protein (SREBP). The protein which is then formed binds to a sterol regulatory element (SRE) on the DNA. This activates transcription of the HMG CoA reductase gene which increases cholesterol synthesis.

Hormones that influence HMG reductase are:

  • Insulin and thyroxine increase the activity of HMG CoA reductase 
  • Cortisol and glucagon decrease the activity of HMG CoA reductase 
  • Statins inhibit the activity of HMG CoA reductase

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is deficient in the autosomal recessive type of Severe Combined Immunodeficiency?
questions.solution:
Adenosine deaminase (ADA) deficiency is the first immunodeficiency disease associated with enzyme deficiency in SCID (Severe combined immunodeficiency).

Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID)

  • Defects in both humoral and cell-mediated immune responses.
  • Affected infants present with prominent thrush (oral candidiasis), extensive diaper rash, and failure to thrive.
  • Some patients develop a morbilliform rash shortly after birth because maternal T cells are transferred across the placenta and attack the fetus, causing graft-versus-host disease (GVHD).
  • Persons with SCID are extremely susceptible to recurrent, severe infections by a wide range of pathogens, including Candida albicans, Pneumocystis jiroveci, Pseudomonas species, cytomegalovirus, varicella, and a host of other bacteria.

Autosomal recessive

  • The most common cause of autosomal-recessive SCID is a deficiency of the enzyme adenosine deaminase (ADA).
  • Deficiency of ADA leads to the accumulation of deoxyadenosine and its derivatives (e.g., deoxy-ATP), which are toxic to rapidly dividing immature lymphocytes, especially those of the T-cell lineage. Hence, there may be a greater reduction in the number of T lymphocytes than of B lymphocytes.
  • In the two most common forms (γc mutation and ADA deficiency), the thymus is small and devoid of lymphoid cells.
  • In SCID caused by ADA deficiency, remnants of Hassall’s corpuscles can be found.

X-linked SCID.

  • The most common form, accounting for 50% to 60% of cases, is X-linked, and hence, SCID is more common in boys than in girls.
  • The genetic defect in the X-linked form is a mutation in the common γ-chain (γc) subunit of cytokine receptors.  
  • X-linked SCID is the first human disease in which gene therapy has been successful.

Other options:

Option A – Ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency causes increased ammonia concentrations causing ataxia and death. It is one of the most common urea cycle disorders.

Option B– Phosphomannose isomerase deficiency is a disorder of glycosylation and features include failure to thrive, enteropathy, and hepatic fibrosis.

Option D-Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyl transferase (HPRT) enzyme deficiency leads to a disease called Lesch-Nyhan disease (LND)

questions.text: Which of the following is considered as a universal methyl group donor in various biochemical reactions?
questions.solution:
Methionine in the form of S-adenosyl methionine is used for various biochemical reactions and is considered the universal methyl group donor. 

S-adenosyl methionine is made from methionine and ATP and the reaction is catalyzed by the enzyme methionine adenosyltransferase(MAT) which has 3 isoenzymes. MAT-1 and MAT-3 are seen in the liver whereas MAT-2 is seen in non-hepatic tissues. 

Function of S-Adenosyl methionine:

1. Transmethylation reactions:

  • Norepinephrine to Epinephrine
  • Ethanolamine to Choline
  • Acetyl serotonin to Melatonin
  • Guanidinoacetate to Creatine

2.  DNA methylation

3.  Polyamine synthesis:

  • Cadaverine
  • Putrescine
  • Spermidine
  • Spermine

questions.text: Thermogenin protein is mainly found in ____.
questions.solution:
Thermogenin is an uncoupling protein found in the mitochondria of brown adipose tissue (BAT); this protein is abundantly found in neonates.

  • It is used to generate heat by non-shivering thermogenesis and makes an important contribution to countering heat loss in neonates.
  • The uncoupling mechanism of thermogenin is by increasing the permeability of the inner mitochondrial membrane, allowing protons that have been pumped into the intermembrane space to return to the mitochondrial matrix. It uncouples the electron transport chain, allowing for fasting substrate oxidation with a low rate of adenosine triphosphate (ATP) production.

questions.text: A young boy presented with fissured tongue, lips, and lesions in the angle of the mouth as shown below. On investigation, he had low RBC glutathione reductase activity. Which vitamin is deficient here?
questions.solution:
Clinical presentation of this patient showing cheilosis and stomatitis, combined with low RBC glutathione reductase activity is consistent with riboflavin (vitamin B2) deficiency.

The deficiency state of riboflavin is characterized by the following signs and symptoms:

  1. Cheilosis: pallor in the angle of mouth and fissuring of lips, which extends radially to skin
  2. Glossitis: tongue becomes smooth, loss of papilla (magenta-colored tongue)
  3. Eyes: keratitis, conjunctivitis, corneal vascularisation
  4. Other features: Seborrheic dermatitis, Anemia

The nutritional status of riboflavin can be assessed by measuring the activity of the RBC glutathione reductase, by FAD added in vitro (this test is specific for riboflavin deficiency).

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy rapidly develops hypoglycemia after moderate activity. Blood examination reveals raised levels of ketone bodies, lactic acid, and triglycerides. On examination, the liver and kidneys are found to be enlarged. Which of the following deficiency would be seen in the liver of this child ?
questions.solution:
The given features are consistent with von Gierke's disease (most common glycogen storage disease) and thus glucose-6-phosphate will be deposited more as there is a deficiency of the Glucose-6-phosphatase enzyme(common to both glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis).

Inheritance: Autosomal recessive. 

Glycogen accumulation occurs in the liver and renal tubular cells.

Features:

  • Severe hypoglycemia
  • Ketosis
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Hypertriglyceridemia
  • Hyperuricemia

 A definitive diagnosis is made using a liver biopsy. Fructose and galactose restriction in the diet is advised.

Complications of von Gierke's disease:

  • Polycystic ovaries
  • Osteopenia
  • Hepatic adenoma
  • Pulmonary hypertension
  • Pancreatitis.
  • Renal failure.

questions.text:
Which of the following options is correct with respect to a fed state?

1)Insulin secretion is more

2)Glucagon secretion is less

questions.solution:
In the well-fed state/ absorptive state of two to four hours after a meal, dietary glucose is the main source of fuel and thus insulin secretion is more and glucagon secretion is less, thus options 1 and 2 are correct.

High-insulin/glucagon ratio indicates high insulin and low glucagon levels, which are observed in the fed state. In the fed state, glycogen storage occurs whereas glycogen breakdown, ketogenesis, and gluconeogenesis does not happen.

questions.text: Which of the following vitamins is wrongly matched with their associated enzymes?

choices.text: Vitamin B9 (Folic acid) : FIGLU excretion/Histidine load test
Vitamin C  : Serum methyl malonate level

questions.solution:
Option D is wrongly matched as Vitamin B12 is associated with serum methyl malonyl levels and not Vitamin C. 

There are two vitamin B12-dependent enzymes:

  • Methionine synthase (Homocysteine methyltransferase): Catalyzes the conversion of homocysteine to methionine
  • Methylmalonyl CoA mutase: Methylmalonyl CoA, formed as an intermediate in the catabolism of valine, isoleucine, and propionyl CoA is converted to succinyl CoA

The below figure shows B12 serving as a cofactor of methionine synthase. Its deficiency may cause  folate trap.

Other options:

Option A: Thiamine pyrophosphate (Vit B1) is the cofactor of transketolase. Transketolase and transaldolase are involved in the nonoxidative phase of the HMP pathway.

Option B: Riboflavin deficiency is assessed by measurement of the activation of erythrocyte glutathione reductase by FAD added in vitro. Riboflavin provides the reactive moieties of the coenzymes flavin mononucleotide (FMN) and flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD).

Option C: FIGLU is converted to L-Glutamate by the enzyme glutamate formimino transferase. This enzyme uses folate (vitamin B9). In Vitamin B9 deficiency, FIGLU accumulates in the body and is excreted in the urine. The FIGLU excretion test is used to detect folic acid deficiency.

questions.text: Which of the following processes does not occur in muscles?
questions.solution:
Ketogenesis occurs in the liver and not in the muscles. Muscles can use ketone bodies for energy, especially during prolonged fasting or intense exercise, but they do not produce them.

Ketogenesis occurs primarily in the mitochondria of liver cells. Fatty acids are brought into the mitochondria via carnitine palmitoyltransferase (CPT-1) and then broken down into acetyl CoA via beta-oxidation. Two acetyl-CoA molecules are converted into acetoacetyl-CoA via the enzyme thiolase; this is also known as acetyl coenzyme A acetyltransferase (ACAT). Acetoacetyl-CoA is converted to HMG-CoA via the enzyme HMG-CoA synthase. HMG-CoA lyase then converts HMG-CoA to acetoacetate. Acetoacetate can be converted to either acetone through non-enzymatic decarboxylation or to beta-hydroxybutyrate via beta-hydroxybutyrate dehydrogenase.

Other options :

Option A: Glycogenolysis is the breakdown of glycogen into glucose-1-phosphate, which can then be converted to glucose-6-phosphate and enter glycolysis for energy production.

Option C: Glycogenesis is the synthesis of glycogen from glucose molecules, allowing for the storage of glucose as glycogen for future energy needs.

Option D: Lipolysis is the breakdown of triglycerides into fatty acids and glycerol, which can be utilized for energy production through fatty acid oxidation.

Related Pearl: Ketogenesis

questions.text: The most important source of reducing equivalents for fatty acid synthesis in the liver is
questions.solution:
The most important source of reducing equivalents (NADPH) for fatty acid synthesis in the liver is the hexose monophosphate shunt pathway (HMP) pathway.

Since HMP shunt pathway and fatty acid synthesis both occur in the cytosol of the cell, there are no membranes or permeability barriers against the transfer of NADPH. This NADPH is involved as a donor of reducing equivalents in both the reduction of the 3-ketoacyl and of the 2,3-unsaturated acyl derivatives. 

Other sources are:

  • Extramitochondrial isocitrate dehydrogenase (minor source)
  • Malic enzyme

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl was brought to the outpatient department by her mother saying she noted some abnormality in her genital area. On examination, there was presence of pubic and axillary hair. Which of the following is the least likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of pubic and axillary hair in a five-year-old girl is suggestive of precocious puberty and 17-Hydroxylase deficiency is least likely to cause it. 

In 17-hydroxylase deficiency, patients are unable to synthesize sex hormones. Females are normal at birth and present with complaints of delayed puberty, primary amenorrhea, and a lack of secondary sexual characteristics in later life. The affected males are incompletely virilized and present as phenotypic females but undescended testes are usually palpable in the inguinal region.

In both 21-hydroxylase and 11β-hydroxylase deficiencies, the respective precursors to the hormones are shunted to the androgen synthesis pathway, resulting in all the signs and symptoms of androgen excess. Female babies are typically born with signs of virilization like ambiguous genitalia characterized by clitoral enlargement and labial fusion. Whereas, the males have normal-appearing genitalia at birth and present at 2 to 4 years with precocious puberty like early pubarche, a growth spurt, and adult body odour.

Since this child is having features of ambiguous genitalia and virilization, it is unlikely that she would have a 17-Hydroxylase deficiency.

Related Pearl: Variants of Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH)

Salt retention and  hypertension

virilized (DHEA is a weak androgen)

Note: In 11β-Hydroxylase deficiency, Aldosterone synthetic capacity is normal and some corticosterone is synthesized from progesterone by intact aldosterone synthase enzyme. Thus, it is unusual for patients to manifest signs of adrenal insufficiency.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman who was on a diet consisting predominantly of packaged and reheated meals presents with iron-deficiency anemia, painful and tender joints, and bleeding manifestations. Which of the following antioxidant deficiency can lead to these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Diet deficient in vitamin C or ascorbic acid, can lead to microcytic-hypochromic anemia, defective collagen synthesis, and bleeding manifestations.

Vitamin C is a water-soluble vitamin. Ascorbic acid cannot be synthesized in human beings because of the absence of L-gulonolactone oxidase. Gooseberries and citrus fruits are rich sources of vitamin C. 

It is mainly required for hydroxylation reactions. It also maintains vitamin E and many metal cofactors (eg. copper) in a reduced state. The active form of vitamin C is ascorbic acid.

Iron absorption is enhanced by vitamin C. It reduces the ferric iron to its ferrous form, thereby helping in the process of absorption of dietary iron from the intestine.

Vitamin C deficiency causes

  • Decreased hydroxylation of proline and lysine, which results in defective collagen synthesis and bleeding manifestations.
  • Decreased absorption of iron leading to microcytic-hypochromic anemia

A deficiency state of vitamin C results in scurvy. Clinical features are:

  • Loose and spongy gums along with loose teeth
  • Swollen joints
  • Hemorrhages
  • Bleeding into the skin - ecchymosis, purpura, petechiae
  • Bone changes
  • Microcytic anemia (due to decreased absorption of iron from the intestine)
  • Scorbutic rosary - sharp, tender beading at the costochondral junctions.

Other options:

Option A- Glutathione is present in glutathione peroxidase. This enzyme acts as an antioxidant. It helps in the destruction of hydrogen peroxide and lipid hydroperoxides.

Option B- β-carotene is provitamin A, found in plants. It helps in the formation of retinaldehyde which is utilized in vision, and retinoic acid which plays a role in the control of gene expression.

Option D- Zinc is an essential component of several metalloenzymes like carboxypeptidases, carbonic anhydrase II, adenosine deaminase, the cytosolic form of superoxide dismutase, etc. Chronic zinc deficiency can cause dwarfism, hypogonadism, dermatitis, and T-cell immunodeficiency. Acrodermatitis enteropathica is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by abnormalities in zinc absorption.

questions.text: A patient who underwent surgery for a lipoma 5 weeks back, now presents with a scar at the incision site that is limited to the original wound boundaries. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is of a hypertrophic scar as it stays within the confines of the original wound. Hypertrophic scars rise above the skin level but stay within the confines of the original wound and often regress over time.

Accumulation of excessive amounts of collagen during repair may give rise to hypertrophic scar or keloid. The accumulation of excessive amounts of collagen→ raised scars known as a hypertrophic scars. If the scar tissue grows beyond the boundaries of the original wound and does not regress → keloid formation. Formation of excessive amounts of granulation tissue, which protrudes above the level of the surrounding skin and blocks re-epithelialization → Exuberant granulation

Inadequate formation of granulation tissue or formation of a scar → wound dehiscence and ulceration. The contraction in the size of a wound is an important part of the normal healing process. An exaggeration of this process gives rise to contractures, which are particularly prone to develop on the palms, the soles, and the anterior aspect of the thorax and are commonly seen after serious burns.

Difference between keloid and hypertrophic scar:

Features Hypertrophic scar Keloid
Genetic predisposition Not familial Maybe familial - Autosomal dominant with incomplete penetration
Age Children Adolescents. Middle age
Sex Equal in both More common in females
Race No predilection African American, Asian, Hispanic
Site Anywhere (more common on flexor surface) Neck, chest, ear lobes, shoulders, upper back
Timings 4–6 weeks postinjury Symptom-free interval; may appear years after injury
Symptoms Raised, some pruritus, respects wound confines Pain, pruritus, hyperesthesia, growth beyond wound margins
Regression Frequent spontaneous No
Contracture Frequent Rare
Histology Parallel orientation of collagen fibers Hypocellular, thick, wavy collagen fibers in random orientation

questions.text: During wound healing, the cells that appear first due to chemotaxis , at the site of the wound is ____________
questions.solution:
The earliest cells to appear because of chemotaxis are Neutrophils.

Neutrophils appear within 24 hours but the neutrophil peak is seen on day 2 of the inflammatory phase of wound healing.

Wound healing :

Wound healing occurs in two distinct mechanisms - 

  1. Wound healing by first intention / Primary union
  2. Wound healing by secondary intention / Secondary union

Primary union / Wound healing by the first intention:

This is seen in cases where there is an injury that involves the epithelial layer only. An example of such healing is seen in a clean surgical incision approximated by sutures. The steps involved in primary union are as follows. 

  • Injury causes the activation of the coagulation cascade and subsequent clot formation. This clot attracts growth factors, cytokines, chemokines, and migrating cells.
  • Within the first 24 hours, the neutrophils migrate to the site of injury. Within 24-48 hours, even epithelial cells from both edges of the wound begin to migrate and form a thin layer of epidermis over the wound.
  • By day 3 neutrophils are mainly replaced by macrophages and granulation tissue starts forming. This process of neovascularisation reaches its peak on day 5. 
  • Deposition of collagen and fibroblast proliferation is seen in the second week. By the end of the first month, the scar comprises a cellular connective tissue largely devoid of inflammatory cells and covered by an essentially normal epidermis.

Secondary union / Wound healing by second intention :

Wounds heal by secondary intention when the wound is large involving a more significant loss of cells and tissues. It differs from primary healing in various ways such as:

  • Since the wound is large, the blood clot formed is large. This leads to increased inflammation and increased formation of granulation tissue.
  • The provisional matrix has fibrin, plasma fibronectin, and type III collagen. In two weeks it is replaced by type I collagen. By the end of 1 month, the scar tissue is mainly made of acellular connective tissue.
  • Myofibroblasts present in the connective tissue cause wound contraction.

Note:

However,the cells that appear first at the site of an injury are Platelets, as a part of initially activated coagulation pathways.

Related Pearl: White cell peaks during wound healing

Cell Peak (day)
Neutrophils 2
Macrophages 3
Lymphocytes 7

questions.text:
A person was bought to the emergency department with facial swelling, itching, and hypotension following a bee sting. The mentioned clinical features are due to the increase in which immunoglobulin?

IgA- Immunoglobulin A

IgE- Immunoglobulin E

IgM- Immunoglobulin M

IgG- Immunoglobulin G
questions.solution:
The given clinical features suggest Type 1 hypersensitivity reaction and are mediated by immunoglobulin E (IgE)

Immediate (Type I) Hypersensitivity is also called allergic reactions or allergies

It is a rapid immunologic reaction that is triggered by the binding of an antigen to IgE antibody on the surface of mast cells. It occurs in a previously sensitized individual. These reactions are induced by environmental antigens (allergens) that stimulate strong TH2 responses and IgE production in genetically susceptible individuals. Activation of TH2 cells is mediated by IL-4 and in turn, TH2 cells produce IL-4, IL-5, and IL-13. These cytokines act on B cells to stimulate IgE and activation of eosinophils. IgE coats mast cells by binding to the Fcεg receptor. Re-exposure to the allergen leads to cross-linking of the IgE and FcεRI which in turn causes activation of mast cells releasing powerful mediators. The principal mediators are histamine, proteases, prostaglandins, leukotrienes, cytokines like TNF, IL-1, and chemokines. The clinical manifestations may be local or systemic and range from mildly annoying rhinitis to fatal anaphylaxis.

It occurs in two phases: 

  • Immediate phase is characterized by vasodilation, vascular leakage, smooth muscle spasm (in asthma), or glandular secretions. These changes occur within minutes after exposure to an allergen and subside in a few hours.
  • Late-phase reaction is characterized by infiltration of tissues with eosinophils, neutrophils, basophils, monocytes, and CD4+ T cells leading to mucosal epithelial cell damage and tissue destruction. Late-phase reaction sets in 2 to 24 hours later and may last for several days.

Image: Sequence of events in immediate(type 1) hypersensitivity

Related Pearl: Disorders Caused by Immediate Hypersensitivity

Clinical and Pathologic Manifestations

Fall in blood pressure (shock) caused by vascular dilation; airway obstruction due to laryngeal edema

Airway obstruction caused by bronchial smooth muscle hyperactivity; inflammation and tissue injury caused by late-phase reaction

Increased mucus secretion; inflammation of upper airways, sinuses

Food allergies

Increased peristalsis due to contraction of intestinal muscles

questions.text: A Rh-negative mother delivered an Rh-positive baby and Coomb's test was positive for the baby. What is the mechanism of hypersensitivity seen in this scenario?

choices.text: CD4+ T cell mediated cytokine release

questions.solution:
The pathophysiological mechanism underlying transfusion reactions or erythroblastosis fetalis as seen in this scenario is a type of type II hypersensitivity reaction and is due to antibody-dependant cellular toxicity. 

Other options:

Option C: Antigen-antibody immune complex deposition is responsible for immune-complex mediated (type III) hypersensitivity reaction. These complexes circulate in the body and deposit in various sites (vessel walls, renal glomeruli, joints) to cause inflammation.

Option D: CD4+T cell-mediated cytokine release is responsible for T cell-mediated (type IV) hypersensitivity reaction.

questions.text: Which amongst the following molecules helps in the adhesion of the leucocyte to the endothelium during inflammation?
questions.solution:
Of the above options, selectins help in the adhesion of the leucocyte to the endothelium during inflammation. 

The two major families of molecules involved in leukocyte adhesion and migration are the selectins and integrins. The initial rolling interactions are mediated by a family of proteins called selectins. These are low-affinity interactions with a fast off-rate, and they are easily disrupted by the flowing blood.

There are three types of selectins:

  • L-selectin on leukocytes - CD62L
  • E-selectin on endothelium - CD62E
  • P-selectin in platelets - CD62P

The expression of selectins and their ligands is regulated by cytokines produced in response to infection and injury.

The recruitment of leukocytes to the site of inflammation is a multi-step process, that is mediated by adhesion molecules and cytokines called chemokines. This process can be divided into sequential phases:

  1. In the lumen: margination, rolling and adhesion to the endothelium occurs.
  2. Migration of the leukocytes across the endothelium and vessel wall
  3. Migration in the tissues towards a chemotactic stimulus.

The process of leukocyte recruitment is as follows:

  • Margination: Because of dilation of the inflamed postcapillary venues, there is stasis of blood flow and hence more leukocytes assume a peripheral position along the endothelial surface; this process of leukocyte redistribution is called margination.
  • Rolling: the slowed leukocytes then sense the signals from the endothelium and start rolling on the vessel wall.
  • Cytokine-mediated integrin activation: the attachment of leukocytes to the endothelial cells requires adhesion molecules that are activated by cytokines. The major families of proteins involved in adhesion and migration are selectins and integrins and their ligands.
  • Adhesions: the weak rolling interactions slow down the leukocytes and allow them to bind more firmly to the endothelium. Chemokines that were produced at the site of injury bind to the endothelial cell proteoglycans. These chemokines then bind to the rolling leukocytes and activate them. This is turn converts the ligands for β1 and β2 integrins, VLA-4 and LFA-1 present on the leukocytes to a high-affinity state.
  • This combination of cytokine-induced expression of integrin ligands on the endothelium and increased integrin affinity on the leukocytes leads to firm adhesion of leukocytes to the endothelium at the site of inflammation.
  • Leukocyte migration: this is the movement of leukocytes through intact endothelium, called transmigration or diapedesis. This occurs in postcapillary venules. This migration occurs through the inter endothelial gap towards the chemical concentration gradient created by the chemokines at the site of injury. This occurs with the help of adhesion molecules present in the intercellular junctions such as Platelet Endothelial Cell Adhesion Molecule (PECAM-1) or CD31.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman was diagnosed with a large tumor in the right ovary and histopathology shows it has origin from all three germ layers. Which of the following is the most likely tumor she is having?
questions.solution:
A cyst with all three germ layers is most likely to be a teratoma, also called a dermoid cyst(mature cystic).

Teratomas arise from pluripotent stem cells that differentiate into any of three germ layers forming tissues of all three germ layers. 

A dermoid cyst is the most common germ cell tumor. It is also the most common benign tumor of the ovary in the reproductive age group and in pregnancy. It is bilateral in 10-15% of cases. 

A dermoid cyst is derived from all three germ cell layers, but ectodermal derivatives are most common. Rokitansky’s protuberance is the most common site for the development of malignancy. It is seen as a projection covered by skin, sebaceous glands, sweat glands, teeth, and bones. Sometimes thyroid tissue can be seen on histopathological examination, known as struma ovarii.

The image below shows a dermoid cyst with Rokitansky protuberance.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old male complained of fatigue for the past 1 year. Examination revealed massive splenomegaly. His blood workup shows the following findings. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
  • Anemia
  • Total leucocyte count - 1,50,000/microL
  • Peripheral blood smear - 
    • 60% neutrophils- 6%
    • basophils- 4%
    • eosinophils
    • myeloblasts, myelocytes, and metamyelocytes
  • Myeloid to erythroid ratio- 18:1
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation with fatigue, splenomegaly, and the peripheral blood smear findings are suggestive of chronic myelogenous leukemia(CML).

Chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) is a myeloproliferative disorder with the peak incidence in the fifth to sixth decade of life. The chimeric BCR-ABL gene is created by a reciprocal (9;22)(q34;q11) translocation(Philadelphia chromosome). This BCR-ABL gene distinguishes CML from other myeloproliferative disorders and is detected by fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH) or polymerase chain reaction (PCR).

Clinical features:

Mild to moderate anemia and hypermetabolism, fatigability, weakness, weight loss, and anorexia. Dragging sensation in the abdomen caused by splenomegaly, or the acute onset of left upper quadrant pain due to splenic infarction. The spleen is often greatly enlarged as a result of extensive extramedullary hematopoiesis. Extramedullary hematopoiesis can also produce mild hepatomegaly and lymphadenopathy.

Peripheral blood:

  • Leukocytosis with leukocyte count, often exceeding 100,000 cells/mm3, which consists predominantly of neutrophils, band forms, metamyelocytes, myelocytes, eosinophils, and basophils.
  • Blasts are usually less than 10% of the circulating cells.
  • Platelet count is usually increased

Bone Marrow:

  • Markedly hypercellular marrow because of massively increased numbers of maturing granulocytic precursors. There is usually an elevated proportion of eosinophils and basophils.
  • There is also an increase in megakaryocytes and usually include small, dysplastic forms and erythroid progenitors are present in normal or mildly decreased numbers. Typically there is an increased reticulin deposition, but overt marrow fibrosis is rare early in the course.
  • Sea-blue histiocytes - These are scattered macrophages with abundant wrinkled,green-blue cytoplasm.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old male presented to the outpatient department with gum bleeding and fever for the past 2 months. General examination showed pallor and the systemic examination was unremarkable. Laboratory examination revealed Hb level- 3 gm/dl, TLC- 1500/microL, platelet count- 15000/microL. Peripheral smear shows macrocytes and the reticulocyte count is 0.5. Bone marrow examination revealed fatty streaks and absent megakaryocytes but no immature cells. What is the likely diagnosis?

Hb- Hemoglobin

TLC- Total leucocyte count
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario showing a young male with gum bleeding, fever, pancytopenia, and a low reticulocyte count with bone marrow showing fatty streaks and no immature cells is suggestive of idiopathic acquired aplastic anemia.

Aplastic anemia is a syndrome characterized by chronic hematopoietic failure and pancytopenia. The common causes include:

  • Acquired 
    • Idiopathic (most common cause, about 65% of the cases)
    • Acquired stem-cell defects 
    • Immune-mediated
  • Chemical agents 
    • Dose-related (alkylating agents, antimetabolites, benzene, chloramphenicol, inorganic arsenals) 
    • Idiosyncratic (chloramphenicol, phenylbutazone, organic arsenicals, carbamazepine, penicillamine, gold salts) 
  • Physical agents 
    • Whole-body irradiation
    • Viral infections (hepatitis, Cytomegalovirus, Epstein–Barr virus, Varicella-Zoster virus)
  • Inherited 
    • Fanconi anemia 
    • Telomerase defects 

Pathogenesis involves an extrinsic immune-mediated suppression of bone marrow and an intrinsic abnormality of the stem cells. 

Clinical features and diagnosis:

There is no age or sex predisposition for aplastic anemia. It presents insidiously with features of pancytopenia such as pallor, petechiae, and ecchymosis. Recurrent infections and fever occur as a result of neutropenia. Reticulocytopenia is seen and splenomegaly is characteristically absent. Bone marrow biopsy is used for diagnosis.

Histology:

Bone marrow aspirate usually results in a dry tap. Examination shows a hypocellular marrow devoid of hematopoietic cells with remnant fat cells, fibrous stroma, and scattered lymphocytes. Red cells are usually slightly macrocytic and normochromic. The following image shows a hypocellular bone marrow with little hematopoiesis and several fat cells.

Other options: 

Option B - Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) is an acquired disorder resulting from the mutation in the phosphatidylinositol glycan complementation group A gene (PIGA), an enzyme that is essential for the synthesis of membrane-associated complement regulatory proteins. Red cells deficient in these proteins are susceptible to intravascular hemolysis. Patients with PNH usually present with pancytopenia and reticulocytosis with bone marrow biopsy showing a cellular marrow with marked to massive erythroid hyperplasia.

Option C - Myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS) are a group of clonal stem cell disorders. It is a consequence of maturation defects that result in ineffective hematopoiesis with a high predisposition to conversion to AML. They are characterized by a hypercellular marrow with dysplastic cells on bone marrow aspirate. Marrow changes seen in MDS are given in the pearl below.

Option D - Pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) is caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis and patients often present with fever, productive cough, blood-streaked sputum, night sweats, malaise, loss of appetite, and weight loss.

Related Pearl: Marrow Changes in Myelodysplastic Syndrome (MDS)

The myelodysplastic syndrome can lead to dysplasia of the erythroid series, myeloid series, and megakaryocytes.

Dysplasia of erythroid series appears as

  • Ring sideroblasts- Erythroblasts with stainable iron in the cytoplasm
  • Megaloblastoid maturation- Abnormally large erythroid cells
  • Nuclear budding abnormalities- Nucleus with abnormal shape

 

Dysplasia of myeloid series 

  • Neutrophils with a decreased number of secondary granules
  • Pseudo-Pelger-Hüet cells- neutrophils with only two nuclear lobes

 

Dysplasia of the megakaryocytes- 

  • Megakaryocyte with single nuclear lobe
  • Pawn ball megakaryocytes- cells with multiple separate nuclei

If only one lineage is affected, then it is called single lineage dysplasia. If multiple lineages are affected, then it is called multilineage dysplasia. If the percentage of ring sideroblasts is more than 15% it is called MDS with ring sideroblasts (MDS-RS).

questions.text: A 24-year-old female patient presented with malar rash, recurrent oral ulcers, and multiple joint pain. She has no relevant past history and does not take any medication. On further investigations, thrombocytopenia was seen and the Anti-Sm antibody was positive. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario along with Anti-Sm antibody positivity is suggestive of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

SLE is an autoimmune disease that mostly affects women of reproductive age. It is characterized by the formation of autoantibodies and immune complexes that cause widespread systemic damage. 

Diagnosis of SLE requires at least four of the following categories: 

Clinical features: 

  1. Skin:
    1. acute, subacute cutaneous manifestations (photosensitivity, malar or maculopapular rash)
    2. chronic cutaneous manifestations (discoid lupus, panniculitis, lichen planus like) 
  2. Oral or nasal ulcers
  3. Nonscarring alopecia
  4. Synovitis involving 2 or more joints
  5. Serositis (pleurisy, pericarditis)
  6. Renal: 
    1. Protein/Creatinine ratio of more than 0.5
    2. RBC casts
    3. Biopsy
  7. Neurologic: seizures, psychosis, myelitis, neuropathy, confusional state
  8. Hemolytic anemia
  9. Leukopenia/lymphopenia
  10. Thrombocytopenia

Immunological manifestations:

  1. Antinuclear antibodies > reference value
  2. Anti-dsDNA > reference value
  3. Anti Smith antibody
  4. Antiphospholipid antibody (lupus anticoagulant, false-positive rapid plasma reagin)
  5. Low serum complement
  6. Positive direct Coombs' test in absence of hemolytic anemia. 

Four criteria with one in each category must be positive for it to qualify as a diagnosis of SLE. However, if a renal biopsy is suggestive of lupus nephritis and lupus autoantibodies are positive then four criteria are not required.

questions.text: A middle-aged man working in sandblasting developed hemoptysis, and a productive cough. Chest X-ray is suggestive of tuberculosis. Which of the following is associated with the same?
questions.solution:
Silicosis is associated with tuberculosis.

Silicosis occurs in industries such as sandblasting, pottery and ceramics, mining, and construction. Silicosis patients are prone to developing tuberculosis, in a condition called silico-tuberculosis.

Silica causes pulmonary alveolar macrophage dysfunction and hence, patients with silicosis have a higher risk of developing lung infections from organisms like M. Tuberculosis, atypical mycobacteria, and fungi.

Radiographic imaging of silicotuberculosis shows cavitation.

In silicotuberculosis: it is still unclear whether silico-tuberculotics are really tubercular or purely silicosis, because 

  • Sputum is rarely AFB+ve
  • Children and women of silicotuberculosis patients do not develop tuberculosis
  • The post-mortem on silicotuberculosis fail to prove the existence of tuberculosis disease
  • Radiological evidence of both the condition is similar

questions.text: A 48-year-old patient presented with scrotal swelling. Investigations for testicular tumours  revealed that LDH was raised but AFP was within normal limits. Following orchidectomy, the following histological picture was observed. Which of the following  is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario, high LDH with normal AFP levels, and the given histology picture showing fried egg appearance are highly suggestive of testicular seminoma.

In yolk sac tumors and embryonal carcinoma, AFP is elevated whereas in teratoma LDH is normal. 

Seminoma is the most common testicular tumour. It is common in men between 20-40 years of age.

The patients usually present with a painless testicular lump. If a testicular tumour is suspected, blood samples are taken from the patient for the evaluation of the tumour markers (hCG, LDH, and AFP), and a high inguinal orchidectomy is performed for diagnosis.

Further treatment of seminoma depends on the stage of the tumor. Stage I tumors, whose levels of tumor markers decline after orchidectomy may not require further treatment. Stage II-IV tumors require radiotherapy and chemotherapy. The chemotherapeutic agents used are bleomycin, etoposide, and platin-based agents (BEP).

human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG): Only the β subunit is measured by the most commonly available serum assays. Can be raised in
