 Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH):

  • LDH has limited sensitivity and specificity for seminoma, but LDH levels >2000 U/L are more consistent with bulky disease, and rising levels are an accurate indicator of recurrence.
  •  In non-seminomatous germ-cell tumors (NSCGT), LDH is directly related to tumor burden.

questions.text: What is the gene mutation seen in hemochromatosis?
questions.solution:
Mutation in the HFE gene on the short arm of the 6th chromosome is seen in hemochromatosis.

Hemochromatosis is an inherited genetic disorder. Mutation of the HFE gene leads to excessive absorption of iron which gets deposited in the liver, pancreas, followed by the heart, joints, and endocrine organs. Histopathology shows golden yellow hemosiderin granules in the cytoplasm of hepatocytes which stain positive with Prussian blue stain. Serum iron is raised. Serum ferritin is significantly increased.

Hepatomegaly will be present in the majority of the patients with symptoms. Skin shows bronze pigmentation due to the increased deposition of iron and melanin over the dermis. Glucose levels are deranged or diabetes mellitus is seen due to the direct damage of the pancreatic islet cells by the deposition of iron.

Congestive cardiac failure is the most common cardiac manifestation of hemochromatosis. Features of cardiac failure will develop suddenly, get rapidly progressed, and if left untreated it may cause death. Hypogonadism due to failure of the hypothalamic-pituitary axis by deposition of iron. This may manifest as testicular atrophy or amenorrhea

It is managed by weekly or twice weekly phlebotomy of 500 mL. Chelating agents like subcutaneous deferoxamine, and oral deferasirox are effective. The main cause of death in hemochromatosis is cardiac failure. 

Other options:

Option B: PTEN is a tumor suppressor gene. Mutation of this gene is associated with Cowden syndrome that leads to multiple cancers like breast cancer, prostate cancer, endometrial cancer, and colorectal cancer.

Option C: ATP7B gene mutation causes Wilson's disease which is an autosomal recessive disorder.

Option D: MRP2 protein is associated with Dubin-Johnson syndrome.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male was brought to the emergency department after suffering severe injuries in a motorcycle accident. His blood pressure was 80/60 mm Hg. Ultrasound examination revealed a ruptured spleen. Arterial blood gas analysis was suggestive of metabolic acidosis. The patient most likely suffered from which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The patient most likely suffered from a hypovolemic shock, due to an internal hemorrhage caused by the ruptured spleen.

The hypovolemic shock caused due to a significant decrease in blood or plasma volume, caused by the loss of fluid from the vascular compartment. Hemorrhage, fluid loss from severe burns, diarrhea, excessive urine formation, perspiration, and trauma are some of the major mechanisms of fluid loss that can lead to hypovolemic shock.

Other options:

Option a: Cardiogenic shock is caused due to the failure of the myocardial pump.

Option b: Septic shock is not likely in this clinical scenario, as there is no evidence of any infection.

Option d: Neurogenic shock occurs in response to traumatic spinal cord injuries, which is not seen in this case.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with hypocalcemia, thymic hypoplasia, cardiac abnormalities, and deletion of chromosome 22q11.2 ?
questions.solution:
The given symptoms of hypocalcemia, developmental defect of the thymus, cardiac abnormalities, and deletion of chromosome 22q11.2 are suggestive of DiGeorge syndrome.

In this syndrome, the fourth branchial arch and the derivatives of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches (which contribute to the formation of the thymus, parathyroids, and heart) develop abnormally. This syndrome is therefore associated with multiple deficits (memorable through the mnemonic CATCH - 22)

Mnemonic CATCH-22:

  • Cardiac abnormality
  • Abnormal facies
  • Thymic aplasia
  • Cleft palate
  • Hypocalcemia
  • Deletion 22q11.2  

Thymic hypoplasia with impaired T cell immunity can manifest as:

  • T cells are absent in the lymph nodes, spleen, and peripheral blood, and infants with this defect are extremely vulnerable to viral, fungal, and protozoal infections.
  • Patients also are susceptible to infection with intracellular bacteria, because of defective T cell-mediated immunity.
  • B cells and serum immunoglobulins are generally unaffected.

 Other options:

Option A: Pitt syndrome or Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome or Pitt–Rogers–Danks syndrome (PRDS) occurs due to partial deletion or monosomy of chromosome 4. The main features of Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome are typical “Greek helmet” facies secondary to ocular hypertelorism, prominent glabella, and frontal bossing and microcephaly.

Option B: Williams syndrome occurs due to deletion at chromosome 7. Classical facial features include:

  • Periorbital fullness of subcutaneous tissues,
  • Hypertelorism,
  • A stellate pattern of the iris,
  • Long philtrum,
  • Thick vermillion border of the lips,
  • Wide mouth,
  • Small jaw (elfin facies)

Option D: Cri-du-chat syndrome is caused by the partial deletion of the short arm of Chromosome no.5. Affected children have a cat-like cry, microcephaly, mental retardation, and congenital heart disease.

Related Pearl: Clinical features of DiGeorge syndrome- Mnemonic

DiGeorge syndrome is a cellular immunodeficiency disorder caused by the deletion of a small segment of chromosome 22 (22q11) leading to a developmental defect involving the endodermal derivatives of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches. (Thymus and parathyroid glands)

The clinical features can be remembered with the mnemonic – CATCH

  • C – Cardiac defects
  • A – Abnormal facies
  • T – Thymic aplasia
  • C – Cleft palate
  • H – Hypocalcemia

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with progressive abdominal distention, shortness of breath, and swelling of the ankles over the past 3 months. Physical examination reveals a large pelvic mass, and pitting edema in the lower extremities. CT scan shows a solid right ovarian mass, significant ascites, and right-sided pleural effusion. After surgical removal of the mass, both the ascites and pleural effusion resolve completely, and the ankle swelling subsides. Histopathology confirms a benign ovarian fibroma. What is the mode of inheritance of this syndrome?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes Meig's syndrome, it is an acquired disorder without genetic association.

Meigs syndrome triad:

  • Ovarian fibroma
  • Pleural effusion
  • Ascites that disappear after removal of the tumor

Meigs syndrome is mostly caused by ovarian fibroma. CA-125 levels may also be elevated. As it is a diagnosis of exclusion, a workup should be done to rule out malignancy. Exploratory laparotomy with surgical staging is the treatment of choice. Conservative surgery (salpingo-oophorectomy) is done. The clinical features resolve on resection of the fibroma.

Pseudo-Meigs syndrome presents with ascites and pleural effusion in association with benign ovarian tumors such as teratoma, struma ovarii, mucinous cystadenoma, etc.

II. Sex cord-stromal tumors:

  • Pure sex cord tumors- Granulosa cell tumor (Adult/Juvenile), Sertoli cell tumor
  • Mixed sex cord-stromal tumors- Sertoli–Leydig cell tumors

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents with pruritic hypopigmented macules and confluent patches over the chest. Skin scraping and KOH preparation show an abundance of yeast-like cells and short branched filaments like a 'Spaghetti and meatball appearance'. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of  Pityriasis Versicolor and the causative agent is the lipophilic, yeast-like fungus Malassezia furfur (Pityrosporum orbiculare).

Pityriasis Versicolor is a chronic, usually asymptomatic, involvement of the stratum corneum, characterized by discrete or confluent macular areas of discoloration or de-pigmentation of the skin.

The areas involved are mainly the chest, abdomen, upper limbs, and back.

Skin scraping and KOH preparation show an abundance of yeast-like cells and short branched filaments (Spaghetti and meatball appearance).

Treatment includes topical azoles or terbinafine for 2 weeks.

The image below shows the hypopigmented lesions of P. versicolour over the chest.

Electron microscopic image of Malassezia furfur

Other options:

  • Tinea corporis/ ringworm infection is caused by the dermatophyte Trichophyton rubrum. It results from invasion and proliferation of the causal fungi in the stratum corneum with lesions on the trunk and limbs. 
  • Candida, the causative agent for candidiasis, appear as budding gram-positive cells on wet films and smears. Mycelial forms suggest colonization. Culture colonies are creamy-white and have a yeasty odor. Candida albicans, the most commonly implicated pathogenic species, form chlamydospores on corn meal agar.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes with complaints of fever and increasing fatigue for the past week. On examination, he is febrile, hypotensive and tachycardic. The findings of his peripheral blood smear are given below. What is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the blood smear showing multiple ring forms in RBCs are suggestive of Plasmodium falciparum.

Plasmodium falciparum causes malignant tertian malaria. This means that the fever has a periodicity of 48 hours corresponding to one cycle of erythrocytic schizogony. Malignant because it is a more severe and fatal type of malaria.

Major manifestations of severe falciparum malaria include unarousable coma/ cerebral malaria (failure to localize or respond appropriately to stimuli or coma persisting for >30 min after generalized convulsion), acidosis, severe normocytic normochromic anemia, renal failure, pulmonary edema, hypoglycemia, shock, and disseminated intravascular coagulation. Other manifestations include hemoglobinuria, hyperparasitemia, jaundice, and extreme weakness.

Falciparum malaria shows a very high percentage of RBCs containing ring forms. This high-level parasitemia is more often seen in Plasmodium falciparum infection than in infection by other plasmodia. After the ring form in the peripheral blood, the rest of the erythrocytic cycle occurs in the capillaries of the brain and internal organs. So, only ring forms can be seen in the peripheral blood and not the late trophozoites and schizonts. The gametocytes of P. falciparum are crescent-shaped or “banana-shaped” (as shown below), whereas those of the other plasmodia are spherical.

The treatment of choice is artesunate given at a dose of 2.4 mg/kg stat IV, followed by 2.4 mg/kg at 12 and 24 hours, and then daily if necessary.

In Plasmodium falciparum, recrudescence can be seen which is defined as the recurrence of asexual parasitemia. It usually occurs within 8 weeks of treatment and is due to incomplete treatment or drug resistance.

questions.text: A patient presented with a black, foul-smelling discharge from the nose. On examination, blackish necrotic mass filling the nasal cavity and eroding the septum and hard palate were seen. What is the most important risk factor for this disease?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of mucormycosis and the most important risk factor among these is diabetes. 

Mucormycosis is an opportunistic mycosis. It is typically seen in patients with diabetes mellitus and/or diabetic ketoacidosis, and immunocompromised patients. Mucormycosis recently emerged as an important superinfection in COVID-19 patients, especially in India. The surge in cases is most likely due to diabetes mellitus and steroid use.

Risk factors for the infection include the following:

  • Uncontrolled diabetes
  • Acidosis (especially diabetic ketoacidosis)
  • Steroid treatment
  • Lymphomas and leukemias
  • Immunodeficiencies
  • Severe burns 

The rhino-orbital-cerebral is the most common form of mucormycosis. Patients present with rhinitis, eye or facial pain, and facial numbness followed by the onset of conjunctival suffusion and swelling along with blurry vision. 

Patients can have local tissue destruction with blackish nasal discharge typically resembling the presentation of invasive mucormycosis. The blackish discoloration is due to direct fungal invasion causing arterial and venous thrombosis leading to gangrene.

Diagnosis is made by biopsy with histopathologic examination. The biopsy shows characteristic wide, ribbon-like aseptate hyphal elements that branch at right angles.

The below image shows biopsy findings seen in mucormycosis.

Treatment includes intravenous administration of amphotericin B and wide excision of necrotic tissues. Along with the reversal of underlying conditions and risk factors.

questions.text: A 3-year-old male child was brought to your clinic with an erythematous rash on the cheek which later spread downwards to involve his trunk and limbs. He has also had a low-grade fever, headache, and mild upper respiratory tract infection for the past few days. The suspected organism contains single-stranded DNA. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and image are strongly suggestive of erythema infectiosum. It is caused by Parvoviruses. Parvovirus B19 is a non-enveloped single-stranded DNA virus. 

Clinically, parvovirus B-19 infection may have several presentations-

  • Erythema infectiosum- Also known as the fifth disease. The incubation period after infection is typically around 4-14 days. The hallmark of erythema infectiosum is the characteristic rash, which appears initially as erythematous facial flushing, often described as a “slapped cheek” appearance. Later the rash spreads rapidly or concurrently to the trunk and proximal extremities as diffuse macular erythema. The child may be febrile. 
  • Transient aplastic crisis- It may be seen in patients with underlying chronic hemolytic anaemia like sickle-cell disease, thalassemia, hereditary spherocytosis, and RBC enzyme deficiencies like pyruvate kinase deficiency. Patients with aplastic crisis appear ill with fever, malaise, and pale with tachycardia and tachypnea due to profound anaemia. The rash may or may not be present. Children with sickle-cell disease may also develop vaso-occlusive crises.
  • Pure red cell aplasia- Persistent B19V infection that results in pure red cell aplasia has been reported in a wide variety of immunosuppressed patients, including patients with congenital immunodeficiency, AIDS, and lymphoproliferative disorders and transplant recipients.
  • Primary maternal infection is associated with non-immune fetal hydrops and intrauterine fetal demise.

It is a clinical diagnosis that usually does not require investigations. However, in the case of pregnant women or with other manifestations an IgM ELISA or PCR assay may be done.

It is self-limited and resolves on its own.

questions.text: Condyloma Accuminata is most commonly caused by ___.
questions.solution:
Human papillomavirus 6 & 11 (6 >11) are the most common cause of anogenital warts ,also known as Condyloma Accuminata.

  • Giant Anogenital warts are known as Buschke Lowenstein Tumor.
  • It is more common in males than in females.
  • Most common site:
    • In males: Frenulum, corona, glans penis
    • In females: Posterior fourchette
  • On histology koilocytes are seen.

These are squamous epithelial cells which have nuclear enlargement, irregular nuclear membrane, hyperchromasia, perinuclear halo.

  • Most of these warts resolve spontaneously.
  • Persistent warts might transform into malignancy most commonly when infected with HPV 16 and 18.

Treatment:

Provider administered:

  1. Podophyllin (25%) - Antimitotic drug
  2. Trichloroacetic acid
  3. Cryotherapy

Both trichloroacetic acid and cryotherapy are safe in pregnancy.

Patient administered:

  1. Purified podophyllin called podophyllotoxin
  2. Imiquimod - Immunomodulator which acts on toll-like receptor 7 and 8

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the OPD with complaints of fever, ear pain, and difficulty in swallowing for 1 week. On examination, there is testicular swelling and his jaw is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with fever, ear pain, parotid swelling, and testicular swelling is suggestive of mumps.

Mumps is caused by RNA paramyxovirus. It is spread from person to person via droplets from clinical and subclinical cases. The incubation period is 12-21 days. The virus appears in the saliva from up to 7 days before to as long as 7 days after the onset of parotid swelling.

The patient presents with prodrome lasting 1-2 days consisting of fever, headache, and vomiting. After the prodrome, unilateral or bilateral parotitis develops, which is tender. It may be associated with ipsilateral ear pain. Ingestion of sour or acidic foods may enhance pain.

It can be prevented by administering live attenuated, MMR vaccine at 15-18 months and 5 years.

Complications of mumps:

  • Aseptic meningitis or meningoencephalitis
  • Epididymo-orchitis which is usually unilateral. Seen in post-pubertal males
  • Oophoritis
  • Other complications include pancreatitis and myocarditis

Meningoencephalitis/aseptic meningitis can occur before, along with, or after parotitis. Most commonly, it manifests 5 days after parotitis. It can present with headaches, neck stiffness, and drowsiness.

*Note: Non-mumps parotitis can be caused by:

  • Epstein-Barr virus - causes infectious mononucleosis
  • Coxsackievirus - causes herpangina
  • Parainfluenza virus - causes croup

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with fever, headache, photophobia, and neck rigidity for the last 2 days. He had undergone a heart transplant one year back and is on immunomodulatory drugs. A lumbar puncture was taken in view of meningitis which showed reduced glucose, increased protein, and increased leukocytes with predominant neutrophils. On microscopy, differential motility was seen, non-motile at 37 degrees and tumbling motility at 25 degrees. What is the most likely organism causing this?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and LP findings are suggestive of meningitis. Differential motility with risk factors of immunosuppression suggests a Listeria infection.

Risk factors for Listeria meningitis include:

  • Age>50
  • Diabetes
  • Chronic illness
  • Malignancy
  • Immunosuppressive therapy

Listeria monocytogenes shows slow tumbling motility when grown at 25 °C.

But at 37°C, it is non-motile because the peritrichous flagella are produced by the bacillus optimally between 20°C and 30°C. This is known as differential motility as motility pattern changes with a change in temperature.

Listeria moves from cell-to-cell using host cell actin framework.

questions.text: A patient presented with complaints of fever for 3 days and general fatigue. On examination, splinter hemorrhages were seen. Echocardiography revealed vegetations on the valves and thus a blood culture was done. The organism in the culture was seen as cocci in chains that showed alpha hemolysis on blood agar and was resistant to optochin and bile.  Which of the following bacteria is most commonly implicated in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of fever, splinter hemorrhages, and vegetations in echo is suggestive of infective endocarditis. The bacteria seen as cocci with alpha hemolysis and resistant to optochin and bile is most suggestive of streptococcus viridans and in the following options, Streptococcus sanguis is a type of viridans bacteria. 

Streptococcus sanguis belong to the viridans group of streptococci and they cause subacute bacterial endocarditis. 

Streptococci that show alpha hemolysis on blood agar are again classified on the basis of optochin sensitivity and bile solubility.

  • Alpha hemolysis: Streptococcus pneumoniae is sensitive to optochin and is bile soluble. Viridians streptococci are resistant to optochin and are bile insoluble.
  • Beta hemolysis: Group B is resistant to bacitracin and Group A is sensitive to it.
  • Gamma hemolysis: Enterococcus grows in 6.5% NaCl and non-enterococcus does not.

Viridans streptococci show alpha hemolysis on blood agar and are resistant to optochin. They contain:

  • Streptococci sanguis causes subacute bacterial endocarditis
  • Streptococci mitis
  • Streptococci mutans
  • Streptococci salvarius

Other options:

Option A- Streptococcus pyogenes are beta-hemolytic and bacitracin sensitive. 

Option C- Enterococcus does not show hemolysis. 

Option D- Streptococcus agalacticae shows beta hemolysis and is bacitracin resistant.

questions.text: A 70-year- old woman was diagnosed with right leg cellulitis and was admitted in hospital for 3 days. She was prescribed clindamycin. Two days after her discharge, she developed diarrhoea and abdominal pain. Her temperature was 38.8 degrees. Her blood reports revealed a Hb level of 12g/dl; WBC count of 18,000/mm3; CRP of 160mg/l. What is the most probable etiological agent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of a patient with diarrhoea following antibiotic administration is suggestive of pseudomembranous colitis due to Clostridium difficile. 

Clostridium difficile is the most common cause of infectious diarrhoea in nosocomial infections. It is the most common antibiotic-associated diarrhoea. It is commonly seen in individuals who receive a prolonged antibiotic course, which causes a change in the composition of gastrointestinal microbial flora, leading to the colonization of C. difficile.

Clinical features:

  • Lower abdominal pain with loose watery diarrhea.
  • Fever, leukocytosis
  • In some patients, the disease may progress to life-threatening pseudomembranous colitis.

Investigations:

  • Nucleic acid amplification tests, including PCR assays, for C. difficile toxin A or B gene in stool 
  • Stool culture in selective media
  • Demonstrating toxin by Hep-2 cell cultures
  • Toxin gene identification by enzyme immunoassay
  • Colonoscopy or sigmoidoscopy reveals a characteristic appearance, with erythema, white plaques, or an adherent pseudomembrane.

Nucleic acid amplification tests, including PCR assays, for C. difficile toxin A or B gene in the stool are used as they are both rapid and sensitive while retaining high specificity.

Oral vancomycin, metronidazole, and fidaxomicin are used for the treatment of pseudomembranous colitis, depending on its severity. 

First choice treatment of C. difficile colitis:

Severity Treatment
Mild to moderate Oral Vancomycin
Severe (WBC >15,000/cu.mm, Creatinine >1.5 times baseline) Oral Vancomycin
Severe, Complicated (Shock, Ileus, Toxic Megacolon) Oral Vancomycin + IV Metronidazole ± Rectal Vancomycin
Recurrent/ multiple episodes Fecal Microbiota Transplantation (FMT)

Fidaxomicin is an alternative in all cases. Metronidazole is now reserved for non-severe infections in settings where access to first-line drugs is limited or cost is an issue. 

Recent update: Harrison's 20th edition recommends the use of vancomycin over metronidazole in the treatment of initial episodes which are mild to moderate in severity. Metronidazole is recommended only if vancomycin or fidaxomicin are not accessible. Oral metronidazole is less effective than the other options and may necessitate a longer treatment course for response.

Other options: Escherichia coli, Norovirus, Rotavirus are all causes of Traveller's diarrhea.

Other causes for Nosocomial diarrhea:

  • Clostridium perfringens,
  • Klebsiella oxytoca,
  • Staphylococcus aureus.

Related Pearl: Diagnostic criteria for Clostridium difficile infection

 

The diagnosis of CDI is based on a combination of clinical criteria:

1.Diarrhea (≥3 unformed stools per 24 h for ≥2 days) with no other recognized cause      

2.Detection of toxins A or B in the stool by PCR or culture

               or               

 Detection of pseudomembranes in the colon

questions.text: A patient has complaints of fever with a mild headache associated with some difficulty in swallowing. A throat examination reveals swollen glands and a thick, whitish membrane over his tonsils which bleeds on scraping the lesion.  A sample is taken from the exudate and a gram stain is done, which is as shown below. What is the organism associated with the disease?
questions.solution:
The history of white membrane over the tonsils and gram stain image showing gram-positive bacilli in Chinese letter arrangement points towards the diagnosis of faucial diphtheria caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

Corynebacterium diphtheria is a gram-positive bacillus with clubbing at both ends. They possess characteristic polymetaphosphate granules also called metachromatic granules or Babes-Ernst granules. On microscopy, the bacilli are arranged at angles to each other which is seen as the Chinese letter or cuneiform pattern. 

Albert’s stain or Neisser’s stain or Loeffler's methylene blue are used to demonstrate the metachromatic granules of Corynebacterium diphtheria. These granules are called as polar bodies as they are situated at the ends of the bacilli.

The systemic manifestations of diphtheria are due to diphtheria toxin. It is an exotoxin that consists of two fragments - A and B. It acts by inhibiting protein synthesis. Fragment B helps in binding of the toxin to the cells and fragment A inactivates the elongation factor (EF-2) responsible for protein synthesis.

The clinical manifestation of diphtheria depends on the site of infection. Pharyngeal/faucial diphtheria is the most common presentation. The patient has marked adenitis, a bull neck, and severe toxemia. Pseudomembrane over the tonsils are characteristic. Bleeding from the tonsils can occur. It leads to life-threatening complications such as asphyxia, circulatory failure, post-diphtheritic paralysis, and toxemia.

Cutaneous diphtheria is due to non-toxigenic strains of diphtheria. It may present as a diphtheritic whitlow or skin ulcer.

The image below shows the pseudomembrane over the tonsil typically seen in diphtheria.

Image below shows bull neck.

Isolation of corynebacterium from patient or close contact confirms the diagnosis. Specimen collection for culture should be done from nose, throat and if possible from below the membrane. It grows readily on Loeffler's serum slope and confirmation can be done by growing on potassium tellurite agar which serves as a selective medium.

Image below shows Loeffler's serum slope.

Treatment of diphtheria consist of administering diphtheria anti-toxin (20,000 - 100,000 units) and supplementing with antibiotics (penicillin and erythromycin).

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with Tuberculosis and while testing for resistance he was found to be resistant to Isoniazid, Rifampicin, Amikacin, and Ofloxacin. What is this type of TB called?
questions.solution:
This patient having resistance to first-line drugs rifampicin and isoniazid along with resistance to amikacin and ofloxacin is a case of Extensively Drug-Resistant TB 

XDR-TB (extensively drug-resistant TB) is defined as multi-drug resistant(MDR) TB (resistant to rifampicin and isoniazid) which is also resistant to one fluoroquinolone (eg. ofloxacin) AND resistant to one second-line injectable drug (amikacin or kanamycin or capreomycin). 

It is usually seen in patients who have previously received treatment for TB and have either failed to complete treatment or relapsed.

Related Pearl: ATT Regimen for TB Patients

As per the latest recommendations from National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP), treatment of TB is now based primarily on drug susceptibility testing. This is irrespective of new cases, previously treated cases or recurrent TB cases. 
All cases of TB are treated with Drug Sensitive TB Regimen, as long as the patient is sensitive to isoniazid and rifampicin. (No classification into category I or II)

Type of TB Case Intensive Phase Continuation Phase
New and previously treated cases (H and R sensitive) 2 H R Z E 4 H R E

Classification based on drug resistance

  • Mono-resistant (MR): A TB patient, who is resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.
  • Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin. 
  • Rifampicin Resistant (RR): A TB patient, who is resistant to rifampicin with or without resistance to other drugs. Patients, who have rifampicin resistance, should be managed as if they are an MDR TB case.
  • Multi Drug Resistant (MDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to both isoniazid and rifampicin.
  • Extensively Drug Resistant (XDR): A MDR TB patient who is additionally resistant to a fluoroquinolone (ofloxacin, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin) and a second-line injectable anti TB drug (kanamycin, amikacin, or capreomycin).

Standard DR TB regimen

Regimen class Drugs Comments
H mono-resistant/ poly-drug resistant TB regimen Lfx R E Z for 6 months
  • 6 months long
  • Oral drugs only
Shorter MDR TB regimen

Intensive Phase:

Mfx Km/Am Eto Cfz Z H E for 4-6 months

Continuation phase:

Mfx Cfz Z E for 5 months
  • 9-11 months long
  • Injectables used in intensive phase.
Longer MDR TB regimen Bdq(6 months) Lfx Lzd Cfz Cs for 18-20 months
  • 18-20 months long
  • Oral drugs only
  • This regimen is used for XDR TB patients for 20 months.

Criteria for patients to receive standard Drug ResistantTB regimen

Standard Drug Resistant TB regimen Inclusion criteria Exclusion criteria
H mono-resistant/poly-drug resistant TB regimen Isoniazid resistant TB with rifampicin sensitive No specific criteria
Shorter MDR TB regimen Patient with rifampicin resistant pulmonary or extra pulmonary TB Non drug sensitivity test based criteria:
  • Pregnancy
  • Any extra pulmonary disease in PLHIV
  • Disseminated meningeal or central nervous system TB
  • Intolerance to any drug in the shorter MDR TB regimen
Drug sensitivity test based criteria:
  • If DST/DRT result for FQ or SLI is resistant (XDR TB)
  • Presence of InhA mutation
  • Resistant to Z 
Longer MDR TB regimen Patients in whom shorter MDR TB regimen cannot be considered due to any reason None

Legend

FQ: Fluoroquinolone

SLI: Second Line Injectable

PLHIV: People Living with HIV

Lfx: Levofloxacin

H: Isoniazid

R: Rifampicin

E: Ethambutol

Bdq: Bedaquiline

Lzd: Linezolid

Cs: Cycloserine

questions.text: Which of the following stains is used for the diagnosis of Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection?
questions.solution:
Ziehl-Neelsen stain is used for staining M. tuberculosis.

Steps involved in Ziehl-Neelsen stain are:

  1. Place sample on slide evenly spread it with rotational movement
  2. Air-dry the slide and fix it by passing it over a flame
  3. Apply carbol fuchsin stain
  4. Wash with water to remove excess stain
  5. Decolourise with alcohol 
  6. Apply methylene blue stain 
  7. Wash with water to remove excess stain
  8. View under microscope

Kinyoun modified it so that heat fixing is not required, it is called the cold method. It involves increasing the concentration of phenol acid and the duration of staining. It is then washed with water and decolourised with acid alcohol. Counterstaining with Loeffler's methylene blue or malachite green is done for a minute and viewed under a microscope.

The image below shows the steps of Ziehl-Neelsen staining.

The best diagnostic procedure for M. tuberculosis is sputum culture.

  • Sputum microscopy is the most dependable and conventional method for demonstration of AFB(Acid-fast bacteria) by ZN staining method.
  • The smears are made from the thick purulent parts of the sputum and then are air-dried, fixed by heating, and finally stained by ZN technique.
  • The stained smear is examined under oil immersion lens (100). Acid-fast bacteria in a stained smear appear bright red against a blue background.
  • At least 10,000 bacilli should be present per mL of sputum in order to be demonstrable in direct smears.
  • At least 300 fields should be examined taking about 10 minutes before giving a negative report.
  • The presence of at least two or more typical bacilli in the smear is reported as positive for AFB (Acid-fast bacteria).

The smears are graded depending on the number of tubercle bacilli present in a stained smear on examination by oil immersion lens.

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in Pathology and Microbiology

Staining technique Uses
H&E Most common stain used in routine histopathology
Papanicolaou stain Universal stain for cytological preparations
PAS Demonstrate glycogen, mucin, fungi, macrophages in Whipple's disease, adenocarcinomas, and glycogen- positive tumors (Ewings sarcoma, renal-cell carcinoma)
Alcian blue For acid mucins: Positive stain for mucins of the intestinal mucosa and negative stain for mucins of gastric mucosa and Brunner's gland
Perl's Prussian blue Demonstrate hemosiderin and iron
Masson–Fontana stain Demonstrate melanin in nevus and malignant melanoma
von Kossa method Demonstrate calcium
Van Gieson stain

Demonstrate collagen in spindle-cell neoplasm; Delineate extent of fibrosis; Differentiate amyloid from collagen
Masson trichrome stain Demonstrate collagen and muscle in connective tissue disorders, muscle and fibroblast tumors, liver cirrhosis, neuromuscular diseases
Reticulin stain Demonstrate reticulin fibers to distinguish epithelial from non-epithelial neoplasm, Hodgkin's lymphoma, early cirrhosis of the liver, myelofibrosis
Verhoeff's method Demonstrate elastic fibers in malignant hypertension, arteriovenous malformation aneurysms, Marfan's syndrome, emphysema lung
Oil red O Sudan Black Sudan III/IV Demonstrate fat/lipids: Fatty liver-fat embolism-fibroma vs. thecoma of the ovary-liposarcoma

Microbiology stains:

Stain  Uses
Ziehl–Neelsen Stain Mycobacteria (all species, including Mycobacterium leprae), Nocardia spp. Cyst of Cryptosporidium parvum, Isospora spp., and Cyclospora spp., Head of sperms

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains These include Eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, Congo red, etc. and are mostly used to stain pathological specimens.
Basic stains.

1.    Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in counterstaining in quellung reaction of streptococcus pneumoniae.  

2.    Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction of anthrax bacilli
Neutral stains

1.    Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

2.    Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and some other spirochete and protozoan blood parasites.  

 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contains more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: Used to distinguish cells by cell-wall type. To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain: Used to distinguish acid-fast bacteria from non-acid-fast cells. Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid – fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia.
Fluorochrome staining: Used for rapid scanning of the smear, where the AFB appear fluorescent green against a black background Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.

C. Special stains

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "Chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (Anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–Starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor White Staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain Calcofluor white, which greatly enhances visibility of fungal element in tissue or other specimens. It is especially useful for the identification of Mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.   It is also used in staining acanthamoeba
Chance's staining For Cell wall demonstration

questions.text: E.coli can be grown best in which of the following media?
questions.solution:
E.coli can be grown best in MacConkey agar.

MacConkey agar is used to distinguish lactose fermentators (seen as pink colonies) from non-lactose fermentators(seen as colourless or pale). It is selective and differential media.

MacConkey agar is Selective because bile salts and dyes inhibit Gram-positive organisms and Gram-negative cocci. It is Differential because the pH indicator turns pink-red when the lactose is fermented.

Contents of MacConkey agar: Mnemonic: PLANT

P – Peptone 

L – Lactose                 

A – Agar

N – Neutral red

T– Sodium Taurocholate

MacConkey agar showing LF and NLF

 

Other options:

Option A: Chocolate agar is used for Hemophillus influenza.

Option B: Thyer-Martin agar is used for Nesseria.

Option C: SDA agar is used for fungal culture.

questions.text: A truck driver came with complaints of a painless indurated genital ulcer after unsafe intercourse. Which of the following can be used to diagnose the condition in a low-resource setting when an active ulcer is present?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a painless, indurated genital ulcer in a truck driver is most likely suggestive of syphilitic chancre / hard chancre caused by Treponema pallidum. The motility of the organism can be demonstrated by dark ground/ field microscopy which can be used in a low economic, low resource setting. 

Dark ground microscopy can be used to diagnose syphilis when an active chancre or condyloma lata is present to visualize Treponema pallidum. Dark-field microscopy images have a dark background with a refractile organism. The dark ground microscope has an optical system that enhances the contrast of unstained bodies. It is generally less sensitive.

Various types of Spirochetes and their appearances under a dark ground microscope:

  • Treponemes generally are short, slender with regular and sharp spirals.
  • Leptospira have a large number of closely wound spirals and characteristic hooked ends.
  • Borrelia is large with irregular and wide open coils.

The image given below shows Treponema pallidum demonstrated by dark ground microscopy and the various appearances of other spirochetes respectively.

Other options:

Option B: Fluorescent treponema antibody absorption test (FTA-ABS) is an indirect immunofluorescence test used to detect specific treponemal antibodies. It is not available for routine testing as it is done only in suitably equipped labs.

Option C: VDRL test is a slide flocculation test in which the serum is inactivated at 56°C for 30 minutes and a measured volume of serum is placed on a special cavity slide. The cardiolipin antigen after preparation is added to the serum sample on a slide and is rotated on a VDRL rotator for a specified period of 4 minutes. In a positive test, the cardiolipin antigen reacts with reagin antibodies present in the infected serum and forms visible clumps. In a negative test, cardiolipin continues to remain as uniform crystals in the serum.

Option D: Treponema pallidum immobilization (TPI) test detects the presence of treponemal antibodies in the serum. Similar to the FTA-ABS test, it is also not available for routine testing.

Related Pearl: Syphilis - Diagnostic Serology

Nontreponemal tests (VDRL, RPR)

VDRL- Venereal disease Research Laboratory test

RPR- Rapid Plasma Reagin test

  • Quantitative tests(titres)
  • Reagin antibody tests; based on cardiolipin antigen
  • VDRL can be used to test CSF whereas RPR cannot be used
  • RPR does not require preheating of serum unlike VDRL
  • VDRL requires light microscope for interpretation whereas RPR can be read macroscopically
  • Decrease in titers confirms treatment
  • Sensitivity of RPR(86%)>VDRL(76%) in primary syphilis

Treponemal Tests

FTA-ABS- Fluorescent Treponemal Antibody Absorption test

TPI-Treponema pallidum immobilization test

TPPA-Treponema pallidum particle agglutination assay

TPHA-Treponema pallidum haemagglutination test

EIA-Enzyme-linked ImmunoAssay

  • Detect antibody to treponemal antigens
  • Qualitative tests
  • Greater sensitivity in early infection
  • Positive even after treatment hence cannot be used to detect reinfection.
  • First test to be positive: FTA-ABS
  • Most specific: TPHA,TPPA, EIA

questions.text: One of the effector mechanisms in cell-mediated immunity involves identifying and lysing target cells whose membrane surface antigens are bound by specific antibodies.NK cells are one of the effector cells capable of this process. What other cells are capable of this process?
questions.solution:
Neutrophils and Eosinophils are capable of the effector mechanism described along with NK cells.

The effector mechanism being described refers to Antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC). Antibody dependent cellular cytotoxicity is seen with NK cells. However, it is also seen in macrophages,neutrophils and eosinophil killing certain parasitic worms like helminths via IgE antibodies.

questions.text: A 21-year-old girl who presented with multiple beefy-red painless ulcers over the vulval region is diagnosed with granuloma inguinale. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The causative organism of granuloma inguinale is Klebsiella granulomatis, a gram-negative bacillus.

Granuloma inguinale begins as a painless nodule that later ulcerates to form multiple beefy red painless ulcers. These ulcers tend to coalesce. There will be minimal adenopathy and progressive destruction of the vulva.

Microscopic examination of smears from the lesion/biopsy specimens reveals pathognomonic intracytoplasmic Donovan bodies and clusters of bacteria with a bipolar (safety-pin) appearance.

The microscopic image below shows the pathognomonic intracytoplasmic Donovan bodies. It also shows clusters of gram-negative bacteria with a bipolar/safety-pin appearance.

Management:

  • Tetracycline 500 mg every 6 h for 2–3 weeks
  • Gentamycin 1 mg/kg IM 8 h for 2 weeks 

Other options:

Option A - Chlamydia trachomatis causes Lymphogranuloma Venereum.

Option C - Haemophilus ducreyi causes Chancroid.

Option D - Herpes simplex virus causes genital herpes.

questions.text: A farmer with a history of flea bite in a godown presents with the features of high fever, painful inguinal lymphadenopathy, vomiting and diarrhea and hypotension. Smears prepared from the discharge of these swellings revealed bacteria with bipolar staining. Which stain will help in the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of fever, chills, lymphadenopathy, and a smear showing bipolar staining of bacteria is highly suggestive of bubonic plague caused by Yersinia pestis. The stain used for this organism is the Wayson stain containing methylene blue.

Plague is a zoonotic disease caused by Yersinia pestis. It is a gram-negative, non-motile, coccobacillus. The reservoirs of infection are wild rodents like field mice, gerbils, skunks, etc. In India, the gerbil (Tatera indica) is the main reservoir. The important vector of plague is rat flea (Xenopsylla cheopis).

Humans acquire the disease by the bite of an infected flea, by direct contact with the tissues of the infected animal, or by droplet infection from cases of pneumonic plague. 

Human plague mainly presents as:

Bubonic plague- This is the most common type of disease. The patient develops a sudden fever, chills, headache, and painful lymphadenitis. Within a few days, the lymph nodes in the groin, axilla, or neck enlarge and are called buboes. This is followed by the suppuration of the buboes. Bubonic plague cannot spread from person to person as the bacilli are locked up in the buboes and do not find a way or easy exit.

Pneumonic plague- It develops as a complication of bubonic-septicemic plague. 

Septicemic plague- It occurs when the infection spreads to the blood.

Laboratory diagnosis- Microscopy reveals bacteria that show characteristic bipolar staining or safety pin appearance when stained with Wayson's stain. Antibodies to the F1 antigen of the bacteria can also be demonstrated by passive hemagglutination. PCR is used for a rapid presumptive diagnosis.

Treatment- Streptomycin, doxycycline, and chloramphenicol can be used.

Related Pearl: Rat Fleas

  • Rat fleas belong to the genus Xenopsylla.
  • Their morphology includes a conical head, no neck, a thorax that has 3 segments and an abdomen with 10 segments.  They have three pairs of legs and no wings.
  • The four stages in their life cycle are egg, larva, pupa and adult.
  • They cannot fly but can leap up to 6 inches horizontally.
  • They transmit diseases by biting, mechanical transmission and feces.
  • Flea indices that are used in flea surveys are general flea index, specific flea index, percentage incidence of flea species and rodent infestation rate.
  • Rat fleas are vectors for endemic typhus (murine typhus), chiggerosis, bubonic plague and hymenolepis diminuta.
  • Insecticidal control is mainly 10% DDT.
  • Resistance to DDT, gamma-HCH and dieldrin has been recorded.
  • Repellants like diethyltoluamide and benzyl benzoate are efficient.
  • Rodent control also aims to reduce flea infestation.

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains

These include eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, congo red, etc.

Used to stain pathological specimens

Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in Quellung reaction.

Neutral stains

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.  

 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contain more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain:  Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid–fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, M. avium, Nocardia etc.

Chance's staining For cell wall demonstration

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl has had 4 episodes of meningitis over the last 4 years, with the disease lasting a few days at a time, leaving slowly resolving neurological symptoms such as visual and memory loss. A CSF cytology shows lymphocytic pleocytosis and a diagnosis of Mollaret’s meningitis is made. Which organism is implicated here?
questions.solution: Mollaret’s meningitis or benign recurrent lymphocytic meningitis is most commonly caused by the herpes simplex virus (HSV). Demonstration of HSV antibodies in CSF or persistence of HSV DNA in CSF can establish the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old obese lady with diabetes was managed with oral hypoglycemic agents. She now presents to the casualty with a hypoglycemic episode.  Which of the following drugs is most likely responsible for her hypoglycemic episode?
questions.solution:
Among the following options, Glimepiride which is a sulphonylurea is known to cause hypoglycemia. 

Antidiabetic Drugs that pose a risk of leading to hypoglycemia (insulin secretagogue):

  • Sulfonylureas
  • Meglitinides: Nateglinide, Repaglinide

The following drugs are not directly responsible for stimulating insulin secretion and hence do not cause hypoglycemia:

  • Metformin
  • Alpha-glucosidase inhibitor
  • Pioglitazone
  • DPP-4 inhibitor: Sitagliptin

Note:

While alpha-glucosidase inhibitors themselves do not cause hypoglycemia, the risk of hypoglycemia is increased when they are taken along with insulin or insulin secretagogues.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department with diarrhea, sweating, excessive lacrimation, and salivation. His pulse rate is 55/min and his plasma cholinesterase level was 50U/mL. Which of the following can be used to treat this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of organophosphate poisoning and IV atropine is the treatment of choice.

The organophosphates commonly used as pesticides are anticholinesterases. Toxicity occurs by excessive inhalation of vapors, ingestion, or percutaneous absorption. It inhibits the cholinesterase activity which results in an increase of acetylcholine, leading to cholinergic symptoms.

The predominant initial signs are of muscarinic excess which includes: (DUMBBELSS)

  • Diarrhea
  • Urination
  • Miosis
  • Bronchospasm
  • Bradycardia
  • Emesis
  • Lacrimation
  • Salivation
  • Sweating

This may be followed by cognitive disturbances, convulsions, and neuromuscular blockade.

Treatment:

  • Maintenance of vital signs particularly respiration
  • Removal of clothing and washing of the skin
  • IV atropine 2- 5 mg. If IV administration is not possible, then 2 mg IM every 5-10 minutes (till muscarinic symptoms disappear)
  • Pralidoxime, a cholinesterase reactivator can also be used for treatment

questions.text:
A 66-year-old man presented with difficulty in urination, back pain, and an elevated PSA blood test. An X-ray revealed two radiolucent lesions in the bony pelvis and MRI revealed several enlarged lymph nodes in the lower abdomen. Which of the following drugs can most likely be used to treat the given condition?

PSA- Prostate-specific antigen
questions.solution:
The clinical features and investigations showing elevated PSA, osteolytic lesions and enlarged lymph nodes are suggestive of prostate cancer. Goserelin is a GnRH agonist used in the treatment of prostate cancer.

Androgen deprivation therapy is the primary medical therapy for prostate cancer. The drugs approved for this indication include leuprolide, goserelin, histrelin, buserelin, and triptorelin.

The agonist action of the GnRH analogs causes increased testosterone production, causing a tumor flare. It can be prevented by concomitant administration of an androgen receptor antagonist such as flutamide, bicalutamide, or nilutamide; until downregulation of testosterone is complete.

The combined androgen deprivation therapy with continuous GnRH agonist and an androgen receptor antagonist is as effective as surgical castration, in reducing the levels of serum testosterone and its effects. GnRH agonist can be used in the early and late course of the disease.

Other options:

Option a: Anastrozole is an aromatase inhibitor, used in the treatment of advanced breast cancer.

Option b: Desogestrel is a synthetic progestin without androgenic activity. It is used in combination with ethinyl estradiol for oral contraception.

Option c: Oxandrolone is a synthetic derivative of testosterone (anabolic steroid). It is used in the treatment of bone pain in patients with osteoporosis.

questions.text: Which of the following medications is safe for pregnancy-induced hypertension?
questions.solution:
Alpha methyldopa is a selective alpha 2 receptor agonist and is safe for use during pregnancy as an antihypertensive.

Antihypertensives to be avoided in pregnancy:

  • ACE inhibitors, ARBs
  • Diuretics
  • Nonselective beta blockers
  • Nitroprusside

Antihypertensives found to be safe in pregnancy:

  • Hydralazine
  • Methyldopa
  • Dihydropyridine CCBs: should be stopped before labor as they weaken the uterine contractions
  • Cardio-selective beta blockers and those with intrinsic sympathomimetic activity: may be used as a last choice.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with lung adenocarcinoma comes for her chemotherapy treatment. She has had multiple complaints of nausea and vomiting during her previous treatment visits. Which of the following is used to prevent chemotherapy-induced emesis and vomiting?
questions.solution:
Palonosetron is used in chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting. 

Palonosetron is a 5HT3 receptor antagonist that blocks serotonin in vagal terminals and centrally in the chemoreceptor trigger zone (CTZ). It has a higher receptor affinity as compared to the first-generation 5HT3 antagonists making it more potent. It is also useful in delayed emesis associated with chemotherapy due to its long half-life. 

During chemotherapy, there is cell lysis and 5HT(serotonin) is released from the gut mucosa. The released serotonin acts on the 5HT3 receptors and activates the vagal afferents in the gut that carry the emetogenic impulses to the nucleus tractus solitarius and chemoreceptor trigger zone. The selective blockade of 5HT3 receptors reduces the emetogenic impulses.

It is used in combination with netupitant in acute and delayed nausea and vomiting. Netupitant is an NK1 receptor antagonist. It augments the effects of palonosetron. This combination is particularly anti-emetogenic when given along with dexamethasone.

Other options:

Option A: Metoclopramide is a 5HT4 agonist and D2 blocker and is used as an antiemetic agent.

Option B: Ropinirole is an antiparkinsonian drug that is a dopamine agonist and is also the drug of choice for restless leg syndrome.

Option C: Domperidone is not used in chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting.

questions.text: Which of the following medications can be safely used for a pregnant lady diagnosed with hypertension?
questions.solution:
Alpha methyldopa is safe for use for hypertension in pregnancy.

Antihypertensives to be avoided in pregnancy:

  • ACE inhibitors, ARBs
  • Diuretics
  • Nonselective beta-blockers
  • Nitroprusside

Antihypertensives found to be safe in pregnancy:

  • Hydralazine
  • Methyldopa
  • Dihydropyridine CCBs: should be stopped before labor as they weaken the uterine contractions
  • Cardio-selective beta-blockers and those with intrinsic sympathomimetic activity: may be used as a last choice

L-thyroxine is a Category A drug in pregnancy and thus is safe.

Note:

Alpha methyldopa: Methyldopa is preferred for chronic hypertension in pregnancy based on its safety and efficacy data for both mother and fetus. Alpha-methyldopa is converted to methyl norepinephrine centrally to decrease the adrenergic outflow by alpha-2 agonistic action from the central nervous system, leading to reduced total peripheral resistance and decreased systemic blood pressure.

Labetalol: Labetalol acts by blocking both alpha and beta-adrenergic receptors, resulting in decreased peripheral vascular resistance without significant alteration of heart rate or cardiac output. Labetalol is now commonly used as a first-line treatment choice in pregnancy.

Hydralazine: one of the safer drugs in pregnancy. Hydralazine causes preferential dilatation of arteries over veins. It causes a selective decrease in vascular resistance in coronary, cerebral, and renal circulation, with a smaller effect in skin and muscle. Because of preferential dilatation of arterioles over veins, postural hypotension is not a common problem. Hydralazine-induced vasodilation causes reflex activation of the sympathetic system through baroreceptor-mediated reflexes resulting in increased plasma renin activity.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of doxycycline?
questions.solution:
Doxycycline is a tetracycline that acts by inhibiting protein synthesis.

Protein Synthesis Inhibitors:

Antibacterial drugs which bind to the 30s subunit of the 70s ribosome are given below:

  • Tetracyclines
  • Aminoglycosides

Antibacterial drugs which bind to the 50s subunit of 70s ribosome are given below:

  • Macrolides
  • Clindamycin
  • Streptogramins
  • Chloramphenicol
  • Linezolid

Other options:

Options A: Cefotetan and oxacillin are beta-lactam antibiotics that act by inhibiting cell wall synthesis.

Option C: Ciprofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone that acts by inhibiting DNA gyrase.

Option D: Tavaborole inhibits fungal leucyl-tRNA synthetase, thereby inhibiting fungal protein synthesis and finally resulting in fungal cell death.

Related Pearl: Protein synthesis inhibitors: Primary subunit of ribosome binding

Mnemonic: 50 CELLS arranged into 30 TEAM

50s subunit binding:

  • C: Chloramphenicol
  • E: Erythromycin (macrolides)
  • L: Lincosamides
  • L: Linezolid
  • S: Streptogramins

30s subunit binding

  • Te: Tetracyclines
  • Am: Aminoglycosides

Related Pearl: Cell wall synthesis inhibitors (mnemonic "BBC Van")

BBC Van:

  • Beta lactams
  • Bacitracin
  • Cycloserine
  • Vancomycin
  • Fosfomycin

questions.text: A patient presents to the casualty with a chronic dry cough with no fever or other associated symptoms.  He had recently been started on an antihypertensive for hypertension. Which among the following is most likely responsible to cause these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Chronic dry cough is a common adverse effect of ACE inhibitors that occurs due to the accumulation of bradykinin, substance P, or prostaglandins in the lungs.

ACE has structural similarities to another enzyme called kininase. Kininase normally metabolizes bradykinin, substance P, and prostaglandins. ACE inhibitors when administered also block kininase enzymes which results in an increase in the concentration of these substrates. An increase in the level of bradykinin/ substance P levels results in persistent brassy cough and angioedema in the patients.

Adverse effects of ACE inhibitors:

  • Hypotension: care should be undertaken in patients who are on multiple antihypertensive drugs or have congestive heart failure.
  • Cough: dry cough due to the accumulation of bradykinin, substance P, or prostaglandins, once they are stopped symptoms disappear after around 4 days.
  • Hyperkalemia: in renal insufficiency, diabetes, or patients taking K+ sparing diuretics.
  • Acute renal failure: In patients with bilateral renal artery stenosis, heart failure, diuretics use.
  • Angioedema: rapid swelling in the nose, throat, mouth, glottis, larynx, lips, or tongue. It is an emergency and treatment is by protecting the airway and administering epinephrine, glucocorticoids, and antihistamines.
  • Fetal abnormalities mostly in the 3rd trimester of pregnancy, cause renal developmental defects.
  • Others: Skin rashes, dysgeusia, neutropenia, glycosuria, anemia, hepatotoxicity,

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease who is on inhaled salmeterol therapy presents to the outpatient department with complaints that there is no improvement. Which of the following drugs can be added to his regime?
questions.solution:
In this case, the patient is already on bronchodilators with inhaled salmeterol. The next step in the management of this patient is to add another bronchodilator like a  muscarinic antagonist that is Ipratropium. 

Treatment of COPD:

  • Smoking cessation
  • Anticholinergic agents- Ipratropium bromide
  • Beta Agonists- Long-acting inhaled β agonists, such as salmeterol or formoterol are commonly used. 
  • Methylxanthines- theophylline produces improvements in expiratory flow rates and vital capacity. 
  • Phosphodiesterase inhibitors - roflumilast is used when FEV1<50%. 
  • Antibiotics- macrolides like azithromycin reduce exacerbations when used over one year
  • N-acetylcysteine has been used in patients with COPD for both its mucolytic and antioxidant properties
  • Oxygen therapy

Non-pharmacologic therapies:

  • Lung volume reduction surgery
  • Lung transplantation

questions.text: A patient was brought to the hospital following a road traffic accident. The patient was disoriented. CT head showed no evidence of hemorrhage, but features of cerebral edema and raised intracranial pressure was seen. Which of the following drugs can be used for the initial management of raised intracranial pressure?
questions.solution:
Mannitol can be given as first-line management to decrease the edema associated with the injury.

If there is an associated bleed then craniotomy and evacuation might be needed as well which depends on the clinical picture.  

Initial management of raised intracranial pressure (ICP):

  • Airway protection 
  • Positioning the head up 20–30° (reverse Trendelenburg positioning)
  • A bolus of mannitol up to 1 g/kg for free water diuresis (the effect is delayed by 20 min)
  • Hypertonic saline (3% or 5%)
  • Maintaining fluid and electrolyte balance
  • Seizure control
  • Sedation using a combination of opiates and barbiturates
  • Ventriculostomy and/or craniectomy may be needed for definitive decompression.

ICP normally varies between 4 and 14 mmHg. Sustained ICP levels above 20 mmHg can injure the brain. The goal of therapy in raised ICP is to maintain the ICP <20 mmHg.

Note: Cerebellar tonsillar herniation through the foramen magnum compresses medullary vasomotor and respiratory centers, classically producing Cushing’s triad. It is comprised of:

  • Bradycardia
  • Raised blood pressure
  • Irregular respirations.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man joins a pilgrimage to a shrine at a mountain peak. At the summit, he develops tightness in the chest, associated with breathlessness and altered sensorium. Which of the following can be given for symptomatic relief?
questions.solution:
The symptoms are suggestive of acute mountain sickness and acetazolamide can be given for symptomatic relief.

Acetazolamide (125–250 mg twice a day), administered for 1 day before ascent and continued for 2 or 3 days is effective.It can also be used for prophylaxis.

Paresthesia and a tingling sensation are common side effects of acetazolamide.

Acute mountain sickness:

When individuals arrive first at a high, altitude, many develop transient 'mountain sickness'.This syndrome develops 8-24h after arrival at altitude and lasts 4-8 days.

Characterized by:

  • Headache
  • Irritation
  • Insomnia
  • Breathlessness
  • Nausea and vomiting

Cause: Appears to be associated with cerebral edema

The low PO2 at high altitude causes arteriolar dilation, and if cerebral autoregulation does not compensate, there is an increase in capillary pressure that favors increased transudation of fluid into brain tissue leading to cerebral edema. 

In high altitude cerebral edema, the capillary leakage in mountain sickness progresses to frank brain swelling, with ataxia, disorientation, and in some cases coma and death due to herniation of the brain through the tentorium.

Treatment:

  • Descent to a lower altitude
  • Diuretics like acetazolamide: inhibits carbonic acid anhydrase, and results in stimulated respiration, increased PaCO2, and reduced formation of CSF
  • Glucocorticoids are administered as well. Their mechanism of action is not clear.

questions.text: The parents of a 9-year-old girl have noticed their often staring blankly which is at times, associated with chewing movements. There were also complaints of daydreaming and a decline in school performance. During the episodes, she did not have a problem with maintaining her posture, and there were no generalised tonic and clonic movements. The EEG of the child is given below. Which of the following is a first-line agent to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
The EEG shows generalized symmetric 3 Hz spike and wave pattern, which is diagnostic of absence seizures. Of the given antiepileptic drugs, sodium valproate is the first-line agent to treat this condition. Ethosuximide and Valproic acid are the only 2 FDA approved first-line antiepileptic drugs for absence seizures.

Typical absence seizures are characterized by sudden, brief lapses of consciousness without loss of postural control. There is no postictal confusion. The following subtle motor signs may accompany the episodes

  • Rapid blinking of the eyelids
  • Chewing movements
  • Small-amplitude clonic movements of the hands

Hyperventilation has a tendency to provoke the absence seizures.

NOTE: Ethosuxamide and Valproate are effective for the treatment of absence seizures. However, between these 2 drugs, Ethosuxamide would be a better first-line treatment choice for uncomplicated typical absence seizures followed by Valproate. Atypical absence seizures respond well to valproate.

Related Pearl: First-line Agents in Different Types of Seizures

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can cause gynecomastia?
questions.solution:
Gynecomastia can occur as an adverse effect of spironolactone.

Spironolactone decreases testosterone production, increases peripheral conversion of testosterone to estradiol, and displaces estradiol from its plasma-protein-binding sites.

Other drugs causing gynecomastia are:

Drugs causing gynecomastia:

  • Alcohol, marijuana, heroin
  • Antiretroviral therapy
  • Anabolic steroids
  • Digoxin
  • Risperidone
  • Ketoconazole
  • Spironolactone
  • α-methyldopa
  • Bromocriptine
  • Cimetidine
  • Phenytoin therapy
  • Androgens- testosterone and its esters (except dihydrotestosterone)

Note:

Clomiphene and tamoxifen are used mainly in reducing male gynecomastia.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of alteplase a tissue plasminogen activator(tPA)?
questions.solution:
The mechanism of action of alteplase, a recombinant tissue plasminogen activator is by promoting fibrinolysis.

Alteplase is a recombinant tissue plasminogen activator and activates plasminogen bound to fibrin, and catalyses the conversion of plasminogen to plasmin, resulting in increased formation of plasmin. This results in fibrinolysis of formed thrombus(thrombolysis). It is indicated in pulmonary embolism with hemodynamic instability, severe deep vein thrombosis, ascending thrombophlebitis, acute ischemic stroke, and acute myocardial infarction.  

Alteplase has the advantage of only activating plasminogen bound to fibrin (clot specific) but not free plasminogen. 

Contraindications of alteplase:

  • Risk of bleeding(including intracranial hemorrhage (Option B), subarachnoid hemorrhage, and those with active internal bleeding)
  • Recent intracranial, intraspinal surgery or head trauma in the previous 3 months
  • Intracranial neoplasm, arteriovenous malformation, or aneurysm
  • Bleeding diathesis
  • Severe uncontrolled hypertension

Related Pearl: Plasminogen activators (classification of fibrinolytics)

Fibrin non-specific plasminogen activators

  • Streptokinase - least fibrin specific and has the lowest incidence of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Anistreplase
  • Urokinase

Fibrin specific plasminogen activators

  • Alteplase - has the shortest half-life
  • Tenecteplase - most fibrin specific and given as a single bolus dose
  • Reteplase

questions.text: A pregnant lady was diagnosed with Extensively Drug-Resistant TB. Which of the following drugs is unsafe in this lady?
questions.solution:
Aminoglycosides are unsafe in pregnancy and from the options Kanamycin, an Aminoglycoside is not used. 

Antibiotics safe in pregnancy include:

  • Penicillin group
  • Cephalosporins
  • Erythromycin
  • Metronidazole (except in the 1st trimester)

Antibiotics unsafe in pregnancy include:

  • Tetracycline
  • Aminoglycoside
  • Chloramphenicol
  • Metronidazole(in the first trimester)
  • Fluoroquinolones

Related Pearl: ATT Regimen for TB Patients

As per the latest recommendations from National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP), treatment of TB is now based primarily on drug susceptibility testing. This is irrespective of new cases, previously treated cases or recurrent TB cases. 
All cases of TB are treated with Drug Sensitive TB Regimen, as long as the patient is sensitive to isoniazid and rifampicin. (No classification into category I or II)

Type of TB Case Intensive Phase Continuation Phase
New and previously treated cases (H and R sensitive) 2 H R Z E 4 H R E

Classification based on drug resistance

  • Mono-resistant (MR): A TB patient, who is resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.
  • Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin. 
  • Rifampicin Resistant (RR): A TB patient, who is resistant to rifampicin with or without resistance to other drugs. Patients, who have rifampicin resistance, should be managed as if they are an MDR TB case.
  • Multi Drug Resistant (MDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to both isoniazid and rifampicin.
  • Extensively Drug Resistant (XDR): A MDR TB patient who is additionally resistant to a fluoroquinolone (ofloxacin, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin) and a second-line injectable anti TB drug (kanamycin, amikacin, or capreomycin).

Standard DR TB regimen

Regimen class Drugs Comments
H mono-resistant/ poly-drug resistant TB regimen Lfx R E Z for 6 months
  • 6 months long
  • Oral drugs only
Shorter MDR TB regimen

Intensive Phase:

Mfx Km/Am Eto Cfz Z H E for 4-6 months

Continuation phase:

Mfx Cfz Z E for 5 months
  • 9-11 months long
  • Injectables used in intensive phase.
Longer MDR TB regimen Bdq(6 months) Lfx Lzd Cfz Cs for 18-20 months
  • 18-20 months long
  • Oral drugs only
  • This regimen is used for XDR TB patients for 20 months.

Criteria for patients to receive standard Drug ResistantTB regimen

Standard Drug Resistant TB regimen Inclusion criteria Exclusion criteria
H mono-resistant/poly-drug resistant TB regimen Isoniazid resistant TB with rifampicin sensitive No specific criteria
Shorter MDR TB regimen Patient with rifampicin resistant pulmonary or extra pulmonary TB Non drug sensitivity test based criteria:
  • Pregnancy
  • Any extra pulmonary disease in PLHIV
  • Disseminated meningeal or central nervous system TB
  • Intolerance to any drug in the shorter MDR TB regimen
Drug sensitivity test based criteria:
  • If DST/DRT result for FQ or SLI is resistant (XDR TB)
  • Presence of InhA mutation
  • Resistant to Z 
Longer MDR TB regimen Patients in whom shorter MDR TB regimen cannot be considered due to any reason None

Legend

SLI: Second Line Injectable

PLHIV: People Living with HIV

questions.text: In patients with indications for warfarin usage, what is the recommended range of INR in a patient with mechanical heart valves ?
questions.solution:
The INR ratio recommended for the administration of warfarin in patients with mechanical heart valves is around 2.5-3.5.

Warfarin therapy is usually monitored by measuring prothrombin time. Prothrombin time is sensitive to the reduction in levels of prothrombin, factor VII, and factor X.  International normalized ratio (INR) was developed to standardize the reporting of prothrombin time.

Other options:

Option B: In most of the patients on regular warfarin therapy,  the INR target is around 2.0-3.0

Option A: The range of 1.0-1.5 is too low for beneficial effects.

Option D: INR >3.5 can result in increased adverse effects and is not recommended for any condition.

questions.text: A 53-year-old female was diagnosed with breast cancer. She was managed appropriately and was advised to start chemotherapy. Further investigations were done that revealed she had heart failure as well. Which of the following drugs would you avoid in this patent?
questions.solution:
In this patient with heart failure, epirubicin is avoided as it is cardiotoxic. 

Epirubicin, an anthracycline antibiotic is an anti-neoplastic drug that is produced from the fungus Streptomyces peucetius.

It works by interacting with DNA directly and affecting transcription and replication. It has the potential to create free radicals which cause irreversible cardiotoxicity and cardiomyopathy which is dose-dependent.

The dose of the drug commonly used is 100–120 mg/m2 every 3–4 weeks. A total dose of greater than 900 mg/m2 increases the risk of cardiotoxicity. 

Adverse effects:

  • Cardiomyopathy is the most common adverse effect and it can be either acute, in the form of myocardial damage("pericarditis-myocarditis syndrome"), or a chronic form of dose-dependent cardiomyopathy leading to heart failure.
  • Alopecia, anemia, amenorrhea, leukopenia, nausea, vomiting.
  • Mucositis, diarrhea, thrombocytopenia.
  • Less common: acute lymphoid leukemia,acute myelogenous leukemia,atrioventricular block,esophagitis,hyperpigmentation,myelodysplastic syndrome

Note :

The toxicity profile of epirubicin is similar to doxorubicin.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common side effect of orlistat?
questions.solution:
The most common side effect of orlistat is steatorrhea. 

Orlistat is an anti-obesity drug that acts by forming a covalent bond with the lipases in the gastrointestinal tract and thus decreasing fat absorption. When a usual dose of 120 mg TID is taken it blocks the digestion and absorption of dietary fat by around 30%. After discontinuation of the drug fecal content returns to normal within 48-72 hours. They can also inhibit the absorption of many fat-soluble vitamins like Vit A, D, E, and K

Side effects of orlistat:

  • Steatorrhea: most common, due to the impaired absorption of dietary fat.
  • Gastro-intestinal side effects: flatus, increased defecation
  • Renal injury: the unabsorbed fat binds with calcium, forming renal stones that can lead to oxalate nephropathy.
  • Osteoporosis: due to deficiency in Vit D and calcium 

Related Pearl: Anti-obesity drugs

Centrally acting anti-obesity drugs: The biologic effect of these agents on appetite regulation is produced by augmentation of the neurotransmission of three monoamines, norepinephrine, serotonin (5-HT) and dopamine.

  • Phentermine – Sympathomimetic (Phentermine is usually used in combination with topiramate)
  • Lorcaserin – Selective 5-HT2C receptor agonist

Peripherally acting medications:

  • Orlistat is a synthetic hydrogenated derivative of a naturally occurring lipase inhibitor, lipostatin, that is produced by the mold Streptomyces toxytricini.

Anti-obesity drugs in development:

  • Bupropion: Dopamine and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor
  • Naltrexone: Opioid receptor antagonist

Liraglutide: Glucagon-like peptide 1 receptor agonist

questions.text: A patient with symptoms of psychosis is prescribed aripiprazole. Which of the following best describes this drug, when compared to other antipsychotic drugs?

choices.text: No intrinsic activity ,high affinity for D2 receptor, less extra-pyramidal symptoms and more weight gain
High intrinsic activity , no affinity for D2 receptor,more extra-pyramidal symptoms and less weight gain
Low intrinsic activity ,high affinity for D2 receptor , less extra-pyramidal symptoms and less weight gain
High intrinsic activity ,low affinity for D2 receptor, less extrapyramidal symptoms and less weight gain

questions.solution:
Aripiprazole is a D2 receptor partial agonist. Partial agonists have submaximal or low intrinsic activity and high affinity.

Partial agonists can behave as an antagonist in the presence of an agonist. Partial agonists block the binding of the agonist to the receptor thereby inhibiting a complete response.

Aripiprazole has lower activity than dopamine at D2 receptors. By occupying and blocking the action of dopamine on D2 receptors, it acts similar to an antagonist. It is used in conditions like schizophrenia where dopamine antagonist activity is required.

Metabolic abnormalities associated with atypical antipsychotics.

  • Increased weight
  • Dyslipidemia
  • New-onset type 2 DM
  • Diabetic ketoacidosis

Atypical agents classified according to their metabolic risk potential

  • Highest: clozapine, olanzapine
  • Immediate: quetiapine, risperidone, paliperidone
  • Least: Aripiprazole, ziprasidone, iloperidone, asenapine

Related Pearl: Important points regarding antipsychotic drugs

Thioridazine:

  • Irreversible retinal pigmentation.
  • Cardiac arrhythmias: QT prolongation.

Clozapine:

  • Mixed 5HT2A–D2 receptor blockade
  • Indications: Treatment-resistant schizophrenia and schizophrenia associated with suicidality.
  • Is the drug with least incidence of extrapyramidal side effect.
  • Important side effects: agranulocytosis, metabolic syndrome, diabetes, weight gain, wet pillow syndrome (excessive night time drooling)

Chlorpromazine:

  • It can cause corneal & lenticular deposits, Vortex keratopathy.
  • Obstructive jaundice

Penfluridol:

  • Longest acting antipsychotic.

Aripiprazole:

  • Partial D2 agonist (all others are D2 antagonists). Hence decreases serum prolactin, thus is useful when other drugs cause hyperprolactinemia.

Amisulpride:

  • Hyperprolactinemia.

Risperidone:

  • Increased risk of movement disorders and elevation of prolactin.

Olanzapine:

  • Increased risk of weight gain, metabolic syndrome, diabetes.

Quetiapine:

  • Lowest risk of movement disorders.
  • Can cause cataract formation

Paliperidone:

  • Active metabolite of risperidone; fewer side effects than risperidone.

Ziprasidone:

  • Prolongation of QT interval.
