questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with diffuse abdominal pain. He has a known history of chronic NSAID's usage. Physical examination reveals rigidity. X-ray abdomen is as shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette with physical examination findings of rigidity, x-ray findings showing free air under the diaphragm with an underlying history of chronic NSAID's usage is indicative of peptic ulcer perforation.  

Adverse effects are generally quite similar for all of the NSAIDs:
1. Central nervous system: Headaches, tinnitus, and dizziness.
2. Cardiovascular: Fluid retention, hypertension, edema, and
rarely, myocardial infarction, and congestive heart failure.

3. Gastrointestinal: Abdominal pain, dysplasia, nausea, vomit-
ing, and rarely, ulcers or bleeding.

4. Hematologic: Rare thrombocytopenia, neutropenia, or even
aplastic anemia.
5. Hepatic: Abnormal liver function tests and rare liver failure.
6. Pulmonary: Asthma.
7. Skin: Rashes, all types, pruritus.
8. Renal: Renal insufficiency, renal failure, hyperkalemia, and
proteinuria.

Management - Initial management includes intravenous (IV) fluid therapy, cessation of oral intake, and broad-spectrum antibiotics. Indications for immediate bowel exploration are

  1. Sepsis/diffuse peritonitis(as in this patient)
  2. Bowel ischemia
  3. Complete or closed-loop bowel obstruction

 

Option A : Intestinal obstruction shows multiple air fluid levels on X-ray. 

Option B: Pericarditis presents with chest pain rather than abdominal pain.

Option D: Gall stones presents with cyclical abdominal pain that increase with fatty meals intake initially and no air under the diaphragm is seen.

questions.text: Which of the following options describes the symptoms seen classically in a patient bitten by the snake shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The image given above shows a common krait . The venom of this snake is neurotoxic and can cause muscle paralysis. The local reaction is generally mild.

The neurotoxicity symptoms that would be seen in the patient include: 

  • headache
  • blurred vision
  • perioral paraesthesia
  • hyperacusis
  • dizziness
  • vertigo
  • gooseflesh
  • Vomiting
  • Hypersalivation

Neurotoxicity effects are completely reversible in response to antivenom or anticholinesterase or they may wear off spontaneously in about a week.

questions.text: A patient was referred by a doctor to a radiologist for a CT scan and the doctor was given money for the referral. What is this unethical act called?
questions.solution:
This unethical act of receiving a commission for referring a patient is referred to as Dichotomy. 

Dichotomy is an unethical act wherein a doctor receives a gift, commission or money for referring, recommending, or procuring a patient for any medical, surgical or other treatments. Fee splitting is unethical in India.

questions.text: A 24-yr-old man presents with an excessive desire for sexual intercourse. What is this called?
questions.solution:
An excess desire for sexual intercourse in males is called satyriasis. 

Satyriasis is also known as Don Juanism. In some men, sexual activity is a means to mask their deep feelings of inferiority. Some have unconscious homosexual impulses, which they deny by compulsive sexual contact with women. Many of them are no longer interested in the women after sex.

Other options

  • Nymphomania: An excess desire for sexual intercourse in females
  • Frotteurism: Sexual gratification achieved by touching or rubbing against a nonconsenting person.
  • Masochism: The tendency to derive sexual gratification from one's own pain or humiliation.

Note: Don Juanism represents hypersexuality in males.

Related Pearl: Sexual disorders

Phase
Characteristics
Disorder
Treatment
Desire
Focuses on the patient's drives, motivation, and desires
Hypoactive sexual desire: Patients have a decrease or absence of sexual fantasies, desires, etc
 
Sexual aversion: A complete aversion to all sexual contact
Address issues like feelings of guilt, poor self-esteem, homosexual impulses, etc
 
Couples therapy may be indicated if due to marital conflict
Arousal
Consists of a sense of sexual pleasure with accompanying physiologic changes
Female sexual arousal disorder: Persistent failure to achieve or maintain sufficient sexual interest or arousal during the sexual act
 
Impotence: Persistent or recurrent inability to attain or maintain an adequate erection until completion of the sexual act
Address issues like guilt, anxiety, and fear
 
Check for use of medications that cause vaginal dryness, like antihistamines or anticholinergics
 
Relaxation techniques.
 
Determine if organic or psychological.
 
Consider plethysmography or postage stamp test
Orgasm
Physiologic state in which sexual tension is released and contractions are produced in various organs
Female orgasmic disorder and delayed ejaculation: Recurrent or persistent inability to achieve orgasm either through masturbation or sexual intercourse
 
Premature ejaculation: Ejaculation before the man wishes to do so, before penetration or just after penetration

Address issues of guilt, fear of impregnation, etc

Use vibrators, education, and fantasy

Behavioral techniques such as squeeze and stop-and-go

Address issues of anxiety about the sexual act

SSRIs to delay ejaculation
Pain
Subjective sense of pain associated with the sexual act. Most likely due to dynamic factors
Genito-pelvic pain disorder: Pain associated with sexual intercourse in either male or female. Not diagnosed when the organic cause has been found or if due to vaginal lubrication.
 
Penetration disorder: Involuntary constriction of the outer one-third of the vagina that interferes with the sexual act.

Help with issues of anxiety and tension about the sexual act

Behavioral techniques, such as the use of dilators and relaxation

Address issues of fear of impregnation, strict upbringing, religion, etc

questions.text: Identify the plant shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
The image shown is of the weed Parthenium hysterophorus.

Parthenium hysterophorus is an invasive weed that colonizes and causes environmental, agricultural, and medical hazards. They grow very quickly and colonize among other plants causing disruption of the ecosystem. The chemicals like parthenin, hysterin, hymenin, and ambrosin present in the plant, disrupt the growth of the surrounding crops.

In terms of the medical hazards, the pollens and other parts of these plants are shown to cause bronchitis, asthma, contact dermatitis, hay fever, and other allergies.

The contact dermatitis caused by it is called 'Parthenium dermatitis'. An image of the most common type of 'Parthenium dermatitis' called 'airborne contact dermatitis' is shown below:

Parthenium is also believed to have some health benefits and is used by alternate systems of medicine in conditions like rheumatic pain, diarrhea, urinary tract infections, dysentery, malaria, and neuralgia.

questions.text: In a  case of drowning, the following finding is seen at autopsy. What is it called?
questions.solution:
The image shown above represents a firm hand grip on weeds and mud, found in a victim of drowning. It is indicative of the last action performed by the victim. This is an example of a cadaveric spasm.

Cadaveric spasm/Instantaneous rigor/cataleptic rigidity/death clutch:

  • It is a phenomenon where a group of muscles that are in a state of contraction at the time of death remains contracted after death till molecular death occurs.
  • It occurs immediately after death. There is no stage of primary relaxation.
  • It is seen in cases of deaths coupled with emotional disturbances like in case of excitement, fear, severe pain, exhaustion at the time of death, cerebral hemorrhage, injury to the nervous system, drowning, strychnine poisoning.
  • It is an ante mortem phenomenon and it indicates the manner of death and not the time since death.

Other options:

Option B: Cutis anserina (goose-skin or goose-flesh), in which the skin has a granular and puckered appearance can be seen on the anterior surfaces of the body, especially on the thighs.  It is produced by the spasm of the erector pilae muscles, attached to each hair follicle, and can occur in the living when the skin comes in contact with cold water. It can occur on submersion of the body in cold water immediately after death, while the muscles were still warm and irritable. It can also be produced by rigor mortis of the erector muscles.

Option C: Rigor mortis is a postmortem phenomenon indicative of molecular death. It is useful in estimating the time since death. The mechanism of rigor mortis is due to muscle ATP breakdown below the critical level.  It appears 2-3 hours after death and is usually preceded by postmortem flaccidity. It involves both the voluntary and involuntary muscles of the body and persists for about 12-24 hours. 

Option D: Washerwoman’s hands is a specific change that is seen in the skin of the palm and sole, which comprises of wrinkled, swollen, whitish sodden appearance of hands or feet. It can also be considered as water maceration of skin of the hand, due to absorption of water into the outer layers of skin. Though the washerwomen’s hand and feet changes are usually seen in dead bodies recovered from water, this cannot be considered as a sign of antemortem drowning.

Related Pearl: Differentiating features between Antemortem amd Postmortem drowning

       Antemortem drowning       Postmortem drowning
Foam/froth at nostrils or mouth Not present
Cadaveric spasm Not present
Lungs usually are voluminous, bulky, water-logged and over-inflated ,called as emphysema aquosum. Passive collection of water  in the lungs without any formation of columns of froth,has been called as oedema aquosum.
Presence of foam, fluid, debris, weeds, vegetation, etc. in the bronchi and bronchioles. Foreign matter may passively find access only to the upper respiratory passage.
Demonstration of diatoms in the lungs, liver, brain, bone marrow, etc. Diatoms may reach the lungs but not to the distant organs because of absence of circulation.
Stomach may contain water and foreign material like sand, weed, dirt etc which may be swallowed while struggling for life. Water could enter the stomach. However, quantity of foreign matter may become the decisive issue.

questions.text: Identify the odor produced by the change seen in the image below.
questions.solution:
The image shows a mummified body and it is odorless.

Mummification is a modification of putrefaction. Dehydration or drying and shrivelling of the cadaver occurs from water's evaporation, but the body's natural appearance and general facial features are preserved.. The mummified body is odourless. It is a late sign of death.

It begins in the exposed parts of the body like the face, hands, and feet. Then it extends to the entire body including the internal organs which may later disappear due to putrefaction and maggot activity. During the process of mummification, the whole body loses weight up to 60 to 70% and all the internal organs become a single mass. 

Factors necessary for the production of mummification are the absence of moisture in the air and the continuous action of dry or warm air. It occurs in bodies buried in shallow graves in dry sandy soils, where evaporation of body fluids is very rapid due to the hot dry winds in summer. Chronic arsenic or antimony poisoning favours the process. Differential decomposition is a condition in which some parts of the body show mummification and other parts show adipocere formation.

questions.text: Identify the postmortem finding in a patient with a stab wound on the left side of the chest.
questions.solution:
The postmortem finding shows blood in the pericardium and it is a case of cardiac tamponade.

Cardiac tamponade is the accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space significant enough to cause an obstruction to the inflow of blood to the ventricles. This reduces cardiac output and arterial pressure causing hypotension. 

They can be caused due to a variety of injuries like:

  • Crush injuries, like traffic accidents in which the wheels pass over the heart, cause rapid displacement of blood from the vessels into the chambers which increase the intracardiac pressure. The increased intracardiac pressure causes the heart to burst open and then the blood escapes into the pericardium.
  • Stab injuries, where the left or right ventricle is pierced which allow blood to escape through the myocardium into the pericardium. The blood in the pericardium causes external compression of the heart thereby reducing myocardial contractility, which is fatal. If the left ventricle is pierced then the thickness of the wall may restrict the bleeding allowing time for surgical management. However, a stab of the right ventricle is rapidly fatal as the rate of flow of blood into the pericardium is higher than its removal from the pericardial sac. Around 200 to 300 ml of blood can interfere with myocardial contractility and cause death.
  • Fractures of ribs or sternum, can cause minor injuries in which the victim may live for some hours or days.However, death may occur from shock, hemorrhage, hemothorax, or cardiac tamponade if it is prolonged or a major injury. 

It is characterized by:

  • Hypotension.
  • Pulsus paradoxus.
  • Increased pulse rate.
  • Prominent X descent.
  • Muffled heart sound.
  • Ewart’s sign (bronchial breathing at left angle of scapula).
  • Beck’s triad: Falling BP, Raised JVP, Small quiet heart.

Investigation:

  • X-ray chest - Big globular heart.
  • ECG - Low voltage, Electrical alternans.
  • ECHO - Echo free zone around the heart.
  • Cath - Diastolic collapse of right atrium and right ventricle.

Treatment: Drainage of fluid.

questions.text: Identify the test shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
The test shown in the image below is the Teichmann test. 

Teichmann test (Haemin Crystal Test): 

  • This test is used to detect suspected bloodstains.
  • A small piece of suspected material is placed on a glass slide. Then, 2-3 drops of glacial acetic acid and a small crystal of sodium chloride are added to the glass slide and covered with a coverslip. The slide is then heated.
  • If bloodstain is present, faint yellowish-red to brownish-black rhombic crystals of haemin or haematin chloride appear.
  • When hydrogen peroxide is added, the haematin crystals give bubbles of gas.

Barberio test:

  • It is used to detect seminal fluid. When saturated aqueous or alcoholic solution of picric acid is added to the spermatic fluid, yellow needle-shaped rhombic crystals of spermine picrate are produced.

Florence test: 

  • This test is used to detect semen. The suspected seminal stain is extracted with 10% hydrochloric acid and a drop of it is placed over a slide.
  • A coverslip is placed over it and a drop of Florence solution (potassium iodide, iodine, and water) is made to run under the coverslip.
  • If semen is present, dark brown rhombic or needle-shaped crystals of choline iodide appear immediately.

Takayama test (Haemochromogen crystal test): 

  • This test is used to detect suspected bloodstains. A small piece of suspected material is added to a glass slide.
  • Then, 2-3 drops of Takayama reagent are added and covered with a coverslip.
  • If it is a bloodstain, pink feathery crystals of haemochromogen or reduced alkaline haematin appear in a few minutes.

Related Pearl: Tests to detect seminal and blood stains

Tests for seminal stains

  • Barberio's test
  • Florence test
  • Acid phosphatase test
  • Creatine phosphokinase test
  • Immunological test to detect Prostate Specific Antigen

Tests for blood stains  

  • Benzidine test
  • Phenophthalein (Kastle Meyer) test
  • Takayama hemochromogen crystal test
  • Teichmann’s hemin crystal test
  • Spectroscopic test

questions.text: Which of the following is an abnormal method used for criminal abortion?
questions.solution:
Abortion stick is an abnormal method used for criminal abortion among the given options.

This is a thin wood or bamboo stick that ranges in length from 12 to 18 cms. This stick is wrapped in cotton-wool or a piece of fabric at one end or for the majority of its length and soaked in marking nut juice, calotropis, jequirity, asafoetida, or paste made of arsenious oxide, arsenic sulphate, mercuric chloride, and red lead, among other things. Professional abortionists (dhais) insert it into the vaginal or uterine os and keep it there until uterine contractions begin.

Dilatation and curettage, Mefipristone, Vacuum aspiration are the routine medical methods used in legal abortion.

questions.text: A lucid interval is classically associated with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Lucid interval is classically associated with Extradural (epidural) hemorrhage, although it may also be seen in a subdural hemorrhage. 

Lucid interval:

  • ‘Lucid’ or ‘latent’ interval -The initial concussion is followed by a phase of recovery before sufficient blood accumulates to raise the intracranial pressure sufficiently for the patient to relapse into unconsciousness. 
  • A lucid interval is a period of normal consciousness and here the person is legally bound by the laws that affect normal people.
  • The presence/absence of a lucid interval cannot be used as a diagnostic criterion for Extradural hemorrhage, as it has been found to be present only in 27% of cases.

questions.text: What is the upper limit of Medical Termination of Pregnancy , according to the MTP Act of 2021?
questions.solution:
The upper limit of MTP is 24 weeks. 

The opinion of one doctor is sufficient for abortions up to 20 weeks. For abortions from 20-24 weeks, the opinions of 2 doctors are required.

Medical termination of pregnancy is legal in India for therapeutic, eugenic, humanitarian, and eugenic reasons. It should be conducted only by registered medical practitioners in government hospitals, or other private hospitals that are recognized by the government. The registered medical practitioner should have assisted in conducting 25 cases of medical termination of pregnancy in a recognized hospital. If a person or hospital goes against this rule, they are liable to be punished rigorously for a period of 2 years, which may extend to 7 years.

Related Pearl: Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act - MTP Act 1971

MTP Act 1971

Indications :

  • Therapeutic : When continuation of pregnancy endangers the life of the woman, or may injure her physical or mental health. 
  • Eugenic : The risk of child being born with serious mental or physical abnormality. This includes first trimester viral infections, maternal drug intake (thalidomide, cortisone, antimitotics), xray or radioisotope treatment of the mother, insanity of parents and viral hepatitis.
  • Humanitarian : Pregnancy resulted from rape.
  • Social : Pregnancy resulted from failure of contraceptives. 

Rules :

  • Only a registered medical practitioner who is qualified (one who has assisted in performance of 25 cases of MTP in a recognized hospital) can terminate a pregnancy.
  • MTP should be carried out in a government or government recognised hospital.
  • Private hospitals may take up MTP if they obtain a license from the chief medical officer of the district.
  • The consent of the woman is required for conducting an abortion. The written consent of the guardian is required if the woman is a minor or mentally ill. Consent of the husband is not necessary.
  • If the woman is not willing, abortion can not be performed on the request of the husband alone.
  • The woman need not produce proof of her age. The statement of the woman that she is over 18 years of age is accepted.
  • It is enough for the woman to say that she was raped, and it is not necessary that a complaint was lodged with the police.
  • Professional secrecy has to be maintained.
  • If the period of pregnancy is below 20 weeks, it can be terminated on the opinion of a single doctor.
  • If the period of pregnancy is between 20-24 weeks, two doctors must opine that there is an indication. Once there is an indication, the termination can be done by any one doctor.
  • In an emergency, the termination can be done by a single doctor, even without the required training, even after 20 weeks, without consulting a second doctor, in a private hospital which is not recognised. 
  • The termination of pregnancy by a person, who is not a registered medical practitioner (the person concerned), or in an unrecognised hospital (administrative head) shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term not less than 2 years, but which may extend to 7 years.

Confidentiality :

The head of the hospital must maintain a register for recording the details of MTP. This register is a secret document which should be kept under safe custody for five years, and each patient is given a reference number. The name of the patient should not be entered anywhere, any case sheet or operation theatre register or any other record.

questions.text:
A young teenage boy presents to the emergency department with a history of drug use at a party a couple of hours earlier. He reports symptoms including sweating, headache, anxiety, and hyperactivity. On examination, he has tachycardia and hypertension. Which of the following substances could he have ingested?

LSD-lysergic acid diethylamide
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical scenario provided, the substance the boy may have ingested is likely cocaine.

Cocaine is an alkaloid deliriant extracted from erythroxylum coca.

Acute intoxication with cocaine leads to symptoms spanning 2 stages :

  1. Stage of excitement/euphoria - associated with hypervigilance, anxiety, hyperactivity along with hyper-adrenergic signs of mydriasis, tachycardia, elevated blood pressure, hyperthermia, and cardiac arrhythmias. 
  2. Stage of depression - associated with loss of reflexes, muscle paralysis, circulatory and respiratory failure, and coma. 

Chronic intoxication is characterized by toxic delirium and tactile hallucination of bugs (cocaine bugs) or vermin crawling under the skin (formication).

Treatment includes intravenous diazepam for controlling seizures. For ventricular arrhythmias, propranolol may be given intravenously. If the patient has psychosis, haloperidol may be given. Treatment of chronic cocaine abuse requires psychiatric support. 

Other options : 

Option A: Shakes, hallucinations, and agitation are symptoms of alcohol withdrawal syndrome. They occur 12-24 hours following alcohol intake. Delirium tremens begin 72 to 96 hours after the last drink. It is due to the long-continued action of the poison on the brain. It occurs in chronic alcoholics due to temporary excess, sudden withdrawal of alcohol, shock after receiving an injury, such as fracture of a bone, or from acute infection, such as pneumonia, influenza, erysipelas, etc.

Option C:  Profuse sweating, diarrhea, and piloerection (gooseflesh) are symptoms of opioid withdrawal. They are associated with nausea, vomiting, lacrimation, rhinorrhea, muscle cramps, and generalized body aches. These symptoms manifest about 12-24 hours after the stoppage and recede within 7-10 days of last use. 

Option D:  Synesthesia or seeing smells and hearing colors and flashback phenomenon (emotional and psychological experiences of the previous LSD) are features of lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD) intoxication. Other features include dry mouth, dilated pupils, tachycardia, hypertension, mood changes, visual hallucinations, alterations in time perceptions, vision, and hearing. Side effects are psychosis, depression, panic attacks, and schizophrenic episodes.

questions.text: Which of the following is part of trotter's triad, seen in nasopharyngeal carcinoma?

choices.text: Conductive hearing loss, Ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia,Palatal paralysis
Sensorineural hearing loss, Contralateral  temporoparietal neuralgia,Palatal paralysis
Sensorineural hearing loss, Ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia,Palatal paralysis
Conductive hearing loss, Contralateral temporoparietal neuralgia,Palatal paralysis

questions.solution:
Trotter’s triad seen in nasopharyngeal carcinoma consists of conductive hearing loss, ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia, and palatal paralysis.

Trotter’s triad consists of the following:

  • Conductive hearing loss due to Eustachian tube obstruction.
  • Ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia due to involvement of the mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve (CN V) which presents as facial pain.
  • Palatal paralysis, due to involvement of the vagus nerve(CN X) which presents as palatal asymmetry.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with ear wax and was subjected to syringing to remove the wax. She developed a syncopal episode while doing the procedure when the tip of the syringe touched the ear canal. Which of the nerves is responsible for this episode of syncope?
questions.solution:
The posterior wall of the external auditory canal is supplied by the auricular branch of the Vagus (Arnold's nerve). When this nerve is stimulated, a vasovagal response is initiated which results in the syncopal episode. 

When the vagus nerve is stimulated, a parasympathetic response occurs leading to braycardia and decreased blood flow into the brain which causes syncope.

Nerve supply of External auditory canal:

  • Anterior wall and roof- the auriculotemporal branch of mandibular division of trigeminal nerve (CN V3)
  • Posterior wall and floor - the auricular branch of Vagus (Arnold's nerve). Cough response while cleaning the ear canal is mediated by the vagus which also supplies the larynx.
  • Posterior wall also receives sensory supply by the facial nerve (CN VII)

questions.text: A worried mother brought her 6-year-old unimmunized child to the ER with complaints of fever, cough, and shortness of breath. Examination reveals a bull-neck appearance and a pseudomembrane over the tonsils that bleeds when removed. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 6-year-old suffering from fever, cough, and shortness of breath with a pseudomembrane and bull neck appearance on examination is suggestive of diphtheria.

Diphtheria is caused by the bacteria Corynebacterium diphtheriae which spreads via droplets through the respiratory tract (most important), cutaneous lesions, and fomites.

Respiratory tract diphtheria is characterized by a thick, adherent pseudomembrane (grey or white) on one/both tonsils and adjacent pharynx. Underlying soft tissue oedema and enlarged lymph nodes can cause a bull-neck appearance. 

Patients with laryngeal diphtheria are at risk for suffocation because of local soft-tissue oedema and airway obstruction by the diphtheritic membrane.

Management includes antitoxin therapy as a single empirical dose of 20,000-100,000 units and antibiotics. Penicillin G/ Benzylpenicillin is the drug of choice for diphtheria. However, in case of an allergy to the same, Erythromycin is used. Other antibiotics used are clindamycin, rifampin, and tetracycline.

A greyish-white membrane forms over the tonsils in the oropharynx and spreads to the soft palate and posterior pharyngeal wall. The membrane in diphtheria extends beyond the tonsils onto the soft palate and is dirty grey. It is adherent, and its removal leaves a bleeding surface. In the larynx, the diphtheritic membrane may cause airway obstruction.

Cervical lymph nodes, particularly the jugulodigastric, become enlarged and tender, sometimes presenting a bull-neck appearance. The patient is ill and toxaemic, but fever seldom rises above 38°C.

D/D for membrane over tonsil:

  • Streptococcus & other pyogenic organisms
  • Diphtheria
  • Infectious mononucleosis
  • Vincent’s angina
  • Leukaemia
  • Candida
  • Agranulocytosis
  • Malignancy
  • Aphthous ulcer
  • Traumatic ulcer

Other options :

Option A: Infectious mononucleosis most commonly presents in adolescents with initial symptoms of fever, sore throat, fatigue, myalgia, and malaise. Pharyngitis is often the most prominent sign, with the enlargement of the tonsils and an exudate resembling that of streptococcal pharyngitis. It can be associated with tender, posterior cervical lymphadenopathy. 

Option B: In acute membranous tonsillitis, exudates from the crypts coalesce to form a membrane on the surface of the tonsil that is easily wiped away without any bleeding.

Option D: Oral candidiasis/Oral thrush associated with candida albicans presents as white plaque-like lesions with cheesy exudate on an erythematous mucosa. They are typically painful and can be easily brushed off.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy fell from the bed and developed swelling in the nose and difficulty in breathing. Examination revealed smooth rounded swellings on either side of the septum, through both the nares. On palpation, it was soft and fluctuant. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette is strongly suggestive of a septal hematoma. The most appropriate next step in management would be incision and drainage of the hematoma. 

Septal hematoma is caused due to collection of blood in between the perichondrium or periosteum and the cartilage of the nasal septum. It may be caused due to trauma, septal surgery, or spontaneously as in bleeding disorders.

Clinically, patients may present with bilateral nasal obstruction, pain, pressure over the nasal bridge, or a frontal headache. On examination, bilateral hematomas will be seen as purplish or reddish smooth swelling on either side of the septum. Palpation will reveal a soft, fluctuant swelling.

All septal hematomas must be drained to prevent the formation of septal abscess or organization of the hematoma by fibrosis leading to a permanently thickened septum. Drainage of the hematoma should be done either through aspiration with a wide gauge needle or through an incision made over the mucosa at the point of greatest fluctuation. It must be followed by nasal packing. Patients should thereafter be started on systemic antibiotics.

Given below are a clinical image and a illustrated image of septal hematoma.

Related Pearl: Septal Haematoma

  • Septal hematoma is a collection of blood under the perichondrium or periosteum of the nasal septum
  • Causes: Trauma, septal surgery and bleeding disorders
  • Clinical features: Bilateral nasal obstruction (most common presenting feature), frontal headache
  • Treatment:
    • Aspiration of small hematomas
    • Incision and drainage of large hematomas followed by nasal packing
    • Systemic antibiotics to prevent abscess formation
  • Complications: Septal abscess, depression of dorsum, permanently thickened septum

questions.text: A young lady presented to the ENT OPD with a history of sudden onset unilateral hearing loss, tinnitus, and dizziness following an episode of acute otitis media two weeks back. Rinne test and fistula test were positive. She had refused treatment then and currently came with complaints of worsened hearing loss in the affected ear. On examination, the fistula test was negative. What would be the most likely finding on the Rinne test in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario indicates severe sensorineural hearing loss as a consequence of untreated suppurative labyrinthitis and Rinne's test is a false negative in this case.

Initially, the patient had a positive fistula test, which implies that the labyrinth is still functioning. Rinne's test is positive which could be due to normal hearing or sensorineural hearing loss.

Currently, the patient has a negative fistula test which implies that the labyrinth is dead. This is an example of severe sensorineural hearing loss and here, Rinne test is a false negative.

If intermittent pressure applied to the external ear produces vertigo and nystagmus, it is a positive fistula test. The pressure changes in the external ear are transmitted to the labyrinth. This is suggestive of abnormal communication between the middle ear and the inner ear. 

Related Pearl: Tuning fork tests

Tests Normal
Conductive 
loss
Sensorineural
loss
Rinne AC > BC (Rinne +) BC > AC (Rinne -) AC > BC (Rinne +)
Weber Center Lateralized to the affected ear Lateralized to the normal ear
Absolute bone conduction Normal Normal Reduced
Schwabach Normal Lengthened Shortened
Bing Positive Negative Positive
Gelle Positive Negative (ossicular lesions) Positive

AC- Air conduction; BC- Bone conduction.

questions.text: What is the Battle sign?
questions.solution:
Battle sign refers to the retro auricular or mastoid ecchymosis that typically results from fracture of the middle cranial fossa following head trauma. It is prominent when there is a fracture of the petrous temporal bone. 

 An image showing Battle sign is shown below:

Related Pearl: Signs of base of skull fracture

Signs of Base of Skull Fracture

  • Bilateral periorbital haematoma (raccoon eyes)
  • Battle’s sign (bruising over mastoid)
  • CSF rhinorrhoea or otorrhoea
  • Haemotympanum or bleeding from ear

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true with respect to the Little's area?

choices.text: Keisselbach's plexus is present in the Little's area.
It is situated at the postero-inferior part of the nasal septum.
Anastomoses of 7 major arteries occur here.

questions.solution:
The correct statement among the following is Option A, Keisselbach's plexus is present in the Little's area.

Little's area:

Little’s area, situated at the anteroinferior part of the nasal septum is the most common site of epistaxis in children and young adults. 90% of bleeds arise from Little's area, where the Kiesselbach plexus is situated on the nasal septum. 

Factors that increase the risk of epistaxis in children when compared to adults, include the habit of nose picking and increased friability of mucosa due to frequent upper respiratory tract infections.

Kiesselbach’s plexus:

Four arteries anastomose at the anterior inferior part of the nasal septum (Little's area) to form a vascular plexus called Kiesselbach’s plexus.

  • Anterior ethmoidal
  • Septal branch of the superior labial
  • Septal branch of sphenopalatine
  • Septal branch of the greater palatine

questions.text: A 14-year-old male presented with recurrent epistaxis. There is no history of trauma associated with it. He also complained of nasal obstruction and rhinorrhea. On examination, there is a firm purplish mass on the posterior nasopharynx. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma.

Adolescent male presenting with recurrent epistaxis, nasal obstruction, and purplish mass on the posterior nasopharynx points towards angiofibroma. The consistency of the tumor is firm but the digital palpation should never be done until at the time of operation, because of the risk of profuse bleeding.

Computed tomography (CT) scan of the head with contrast enhancement is now the investigation of choice. Anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus often called antral sign or Holman-Miller sign, is pathognomonic of angiofibroma.

Surgical excision is the treatment of choice though radiotherapy and chemotherapy monotherapy or in combination have also been used.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to you with complaints of difficulty in hearing in the right ear which is slowly progressive. She also has tinnitus which is pulsatile in nature. On examination,  a reddish mass was seen behind the tympanic membrane and an audible bruit is heard over the mastoid when auscultation with a stethoscope. Her Rinnie test was negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture of a woman with progressive conductive hearing loss, tinnitus , reddis mass behind the tympanic membrane and audible bruit heard over the mastoid suggests a diagnosis of a ‘glomus tumor’.

Glomus tumor:

The cell of origin in the glomus tumor is paraganglionic cells (not perivascular cells). These cells are derived from the neural crest. They are paragangliomas of the glomus bodies found in the mastoid.

Glomus tumor is the most common benign neoplasm of the middle ear.

It is of 2 types:

  • Glomus jugulare: It arises from the dome of the jugular bulb causing neurological signs of IXth to XIIth cranial nerve involvement.
  • Glomus tympanicum: It arises from the promontory of the middle ear and causes aural symptoms, sometimes with facial paralysis.

The rule of 10 is seen in the glomus tumor. It comprises of

  • 10% familial
  • 10% multicentric
  • 10% functional

It is 5 times more common in women. Common presenting features include:

  • Progressive conductive hearing loss
  • Tinnitus in glomus tumors is pulsatile, of swishing character, synchronous with a pulse, and can be temporarily stopped by carotid pressure.
  • Audible bruit heard over the mastoid with a stethoscope in all stages

Investigations would include:

  • Phelp's sign-on CECT scan helps to distinguish glomus tympanicum from the glomus jugulare tumor by identification of caroticojugular spine which is eroded in the latter.
  • MRI gives the soft tissue extent of the tumor.
  • Four vessel angiography is necessary when the CT head shows the involvement of a jugular bulb, carotid artery, or intradural extension.
  • A biopsy is never done since it’s a highly vascular tumor.

 The below-given image shows a triangular red-colored glomus tumor behind the tympanic membrane in the middle ear.

Related Pearl: Signs in Glomus Tumors

questions.text: A school-going child presents with a history of recurrent upper respiratory tract infections, mouth breathing, and impaired hearing. On examination, a high arched palate is noted. What is the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture is suggestive of adenoid hypertrophy. The best line of management is adenoidectomy with grommet insertion.

Indications of adenoidectomy:

  • Adenoid hypertrophy causing snoring, mouth breathing, sleep apnoea syndrome, or speech abnormalities, i.e. (rhinolalia clausa)
  • Recurrent rhinosinusitis
  • Chronic otitis media with effusion associated with adenoid hyperplasia
  • Recurrent ear discharge in benign CSOM associated with adenoiditis/adenoid hyperplasia
  • Dental malocclusion. Adenoidectomy does not correct dental abnormalities but will prevent their recurrence after orthodontic treatment

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with chronic mucopurulent discharge from her left eye and swelling near the medial canthus. Which of the following is the treatment of choice in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of chronic dacryocystitis and the treatment of choice for chronic dacryocystitis is dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) as it re-establishes the lacrimal drainage.

Dacryocystitis is the inflammation of the lacrimal sac. It generally affects infants and adults, most commonly females over 40 years of age. Congenital dacryocystitis is almost always chronic, while acquired dacryocystitis may be acute or chronic.

Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) surgery involves removal of the bone adjacent to the nasolacrimal sac and suturing the lacrimal sac with the lateral nasal mucosa. This allows tears to drain directly from the sac via a new low-resistance pathway into the middle meatus.

One of the sequelae of chronic dacryocystitis is mucocele formation, which when infected, leads to pyocele formation and finally lacrimal fibrosis. Treatment of lacrimal sac fibrosis is dacryocystectomy.

questions.text: Which of the following surgeries use this instrument?
questions.solution:
The given image is that of a Bone punch and it is used in dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) operation. 

Bone punch consists of a stout spring handle and two blades attached at a right angle. It is used to enlarge the bony opening during dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) operation by punching the bone from the margins of the opening.

The given set of instruments is used for Dacryocystorhinostomy.

Instrument 1 shows Muller's self-retaining lacrimal wound retractor. It is made up of two limbs with three curved pins on each for engaging the edges of the skin incision. The limbs are kept in a retracted position with the help of a fixing screw.

  • Used to retract the skin during surgery on the lacrimal sac (e.g. DCT or DCR).

 Instrument 2 shows Nettleship's lacrimal punctum dilator. lt has a cylindrical corrugated metal handle with a conical pointed tip.

  • Used to dilate the punctum and canaliculus during syringing, probing, dacryocystography, DCT, and DCR procedures.

 Instrument 3 shows Bowman's lacrimal probe. It has blunt ends with a central stable platform.

  • Uses:
    • To probe the lacrimal gland in the management of congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction
    • To identify the lacrimal sac during DCR and DCT.

 Instrument 4 shows Lacrimal cannula. It is a long curved hypodermic needle with a blunt tip. 

  • Uses:
    • For syringing the lacrimal passages
    • For injecting air, tryphan blue dye, pilocarpine, and balanced salt solution in the anterior chamber during intraocular surgery

 Instrument 5 shows a Bone punch. It consists of a stout spring handle and two blades attached at a right angle. The upper blade has a small hole with a sharp cutting edge. The lower blade has a cup-like depression.

  • Used to enlarge the bony opening during DCR operation by punching the bone from the margins of the opening.

Instrument 6 shows Chisel. It consists of a blade having a sharp-cutting straight edge with one surface beveled. It has a long and stout handle.

  • Uses to cut the bone during DCR and orbitotomy operations.

Instrument 7 shows Hammer. It is a small steel hammer attached to a corrugated handle.

  • Used to hammer the chisel during DCR and orbitotomy operations.

Instrument 8 shows Lacrimal sac dissector and curette. It is a cylindrical instrument, one end of which is a blunt-tipped dissector, and the other end is curetted.

  • Used to curette the lacrimal sac in lacrimal sac surgery.

Instrument 9 shows Freer's periosteum elevator. It has a rounded handle with two slightly curved, tear-drop tips.

  • Used for blunt debulking and lifting periosteum from bones in confined areas. It is used in endoscopic septoplasty and DCR.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man after his retirement party came with the complaint of sudden painless loss of vision in his left eye for the past 2 hours. Fundoscopic examination shows a similar picture given below. What is the most probable cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given fundoscopic image shows a cherry-red spot, which is a feature of CRAO.

Central Retinal Artery Occlusion (CRAO):

Risk factors include

  • Heart disease
  • Carotid artery disease
  • Mucormycosis
  • Varicella infection
  • Radiation exposure
  • Trauma

Etiology:

  • Emboli - emboli having carotid artery or cardiac origin are the most common cause of CRAO. Other emboli are - cholesterol emboli, calcium emboli, and platelet fibrin emboli
  • Atherosclerosis-related thrombosis
  • Retinal arteritis with obliteration
  • Angiospasm
  • Raised intraocular pressure
  • Thrombophilic disorders

Clinical features are

  • Sudden painless loss of vision
  • Severe oedema- the whole retina looks white in colour
  • Cherry red spots
  • Marked attenuation of arteries – thread-like arteries
  • Interrupted blood flow in vein – cattle track appearance

Treatment is to dislodge the emboli by suddenly decreasing the IOP by I/V acetazolamide or ocular massage. Ocular massage is considered the most effective method. Other treatment options include IV mannitol, vasodilators (nitrates), fibrinolytic therapy, or laser photo disruption in some cases. In cases of giant cell arteritis, steroids are beneficial.

Related Pearl: Important causes of cherry-red spots

  • Commotio retinae
  • Central retinal and cilioretinal artery occlusion
  • Metabolic storage diseases
    • GM1 gangliosidosis
    • Mucolipidosis type I (sialidosis)
    • GM2 gangliosidosis (Tay-Sachs disease and Sandhoff disease)
    • Farber disease
    • Niemann–Pick disease
  • Retinotoxicity due to specific agents, including quinine, dapsone, gentamicin, carbon monoxide, and methanol

questions.text: A patient with corneal scar has a visual acuity of 6/36, which improves to 6/18 with a pinhole. The most likely reason for this is ____.
questions.solution:
The given findings suggest that the most likely reason is irregular astigmatism.

In refractive errors up to 3D, there is an improvement with pinhole to 6/6, if the macula is normal. Pinhole prevents the peripheral rays and also reduces the spherical aberration.

However, in this patient, it improved to only 6/18. A thing to note is that the corneal scar mentioned in the case would make the surface highly uneven, indicating irregular astigmatism. So, the best answer is irregular astigmatism.

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy presents with a history of injury to the eye caused while climbing a tree 5 days ago, resulting in pain, photophobia, and redness of the eye for 2 days. Slit-lamp examination reveals a lesion as shown below. Which among the following is a feature of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and the image suggest that it is a fungal corneal ulcer. Satellite lesions are a feature of fungal ulcers.

A fungal corneal ulcer is usually caused by trauma with vegetative or organic matter. Signs are more pronounced than symptoms. The corneal ulcer appears dry.

Causative organisms :

  • Aspergillus
  • Fusarium
  • Candida albicans

Signs of a fungal ulcer:

  • Irregular margins of the ulcer.
  • Presence of satellite lesions surrounding the ulcer.
  • An immune ring (Wesseley) may be seen around the ulcer due to the deposition of the immune complexes.
  • Slough is usually dry, with feathery borders surrounded by a yellow line of demarcation.
  • Hypopyon may be present or absent. If present, it is thick, immobile due to the direct invasion of the fungal hyphae into the anterior chamber.

Treatment:

  • Topical drugs: These include topical natamycin, voriconazole or amphotericin B drops which are effective against Aspergillus and Fusarium. Nystatin is effective against Candida.
  • Systemic drugs: Severe ulcers with hypopyon, perforation or suspected endophthalmitis might warrant the use of oral antifungal agents such as ketoconazole or voriconazole.

Other options :

Option A: Reverse hypopyon is the collection of emulsified silicone oil in the anterior chamber. This can lead to complications such as glaucoma.

Option B: Dendritic ulcer is seen in epithelial keratitis caused by herpes simplex virus. An image of a dendritic ulcer with fluorescein dye is as shown below

Option C: Ring abscess is seen in helminthic keratitis, especially by acanthamoeba. There is gradual enlargement and coalescence of infiltrates which forms an abcess.

Related Pearl: Clinical differential diagnosis of corneal ulcer

  Bacterial Fungal Viral Parasitic
Risk factors

Contact lens wear

Trauma

Chronic steroid use

Anesthetic cornea

Dry eyes

Exposure keratopathy

 Trauma with vegetable matter

Low immunity

Recurrent attacks

Contact lens wear

Exposure to contaminated water (acanthamoeba)

 
Clinical features

Hypopyon is fluid and mobile

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is likely to have a rapid course, with deep corneal necrosis.

Less pain and watering compared to the extent of vision loss and signs. 

Tend to be indolent but progressive

Hypopyon is thick, immobile.

Relatively more pain and watering compared to the extent of vision loss and signs. 

Recurrences are characteristic.

Disproportionately severe pain is a characteristic feature.

Indolent course and in initial stages, often mistaken to be viral/ fungal infection, leading to a delay in diagnosis

questions.text: A 5-year-old female patient presented for her first complete eye examination after a school vision screening found unequal visual acuity. Her parents have not noted any eye problems. Visual acuity in the right eye was 20/20 and the left eye is 20/80. The rest of the examination including Fundus exam was unremarkable, What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis from the given scenario is Amblyopia.

Amblyopia is an uncorrectable decrease in vision in one or both eyes with no apparent structural abnormality seen to explain it. It is a diagnosis of exclusion. Generally, a difference of two lines or more on an eye chart test of visual acuity between the two eyes or a best-corrected vision of 20/30 or worse would be defined as amblyopia. For example, our patient has 20/20 vision with the right eye and only 20/80 with the left and the left eye even after best-corrected vision couldn't achieve <20/30 vision, the left eye is said to be amblyopic.

Clinical features:

  • Decreased contrast sensitivity
  • Diminution of vision
  • Sunglass effect- brightness is less compared to the normal eye
  • Crowding phenomenon- slipping of images

Treatment of choice:

  • Occlusion of the normal eye (4 to 6 hours/day) using patches.
  • Penalization: Blurring of vision using atropine.

Prism correction is not the right treatment as the child doesn't have strabismus.

 

Other options:

Option A: Brain lesion does not cause difference in visual acuity in both eyes.

Option B: Retinoblastoma can be identified by fundoscopy.

Option C: Congenital cataract presents with loss of red reflex immediately after birth.

questions.text: Which is the most common cause of preventable childhood blindness?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of preventable childhood blindness is vitamin A deficiency.

The most common cause of blindness (including adults), is however, cataract.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image.
questions.solution:
The image shows the inward rolling of the eyelid margin which is called entropion. 

Entropion refers to the inward rolling and rotation of the lid margin towards the globe. It is more common in the lower lid.

Causes include:

  • Horizontal lid laxity
  • Vertical lid instability
  • Over-riding of the pretarsal by the preseptal orbicularis during lid closure
  • Orbital septum laxity

Ectropion refers to the outward turning of the lid margin.

Trichiasis refers to the inward misdirection of cilia, which usually rub against the eyeball with the normal position of the lid margin.

Related Pearl: Surgical Modalities Used in Correcting Entropion

Cicatricial entropion

Senile entropion

Anterior lamellar resection

Transverse everting suture

Tarsal wedge resection

Weiss operation

Transposition of the tarsoconjunctival wedge. (Modified Ketssey’s operation)

Plication of lower lid retractors (Jones operation).

Posterior lamellar graft

Quickert procedure

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presented with a white pupillary reflex for which enucleation was done. The histopathological examination of the specimen revealed Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes. What could be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This child with a whitish pupillary reflex and Flexner-Winterstein rosettes on histopathological examination has retinoblastoma. Flexner Winterstein rosettes refer to an arrangement of columnar cells around a central lumen, which is highly characteristic of retinoblastoma.

Retinoblastoma is a malignant proliferation of immature retinal neural cells and is the most common intraocular malignancy in children. It is associated with mutations in the RB1 gene at chromosome 13q14. It belongs to small round blue cell tumours because the immature retinal neural cells are seen as small round cells with large nuclei.

White pupillary reflex or leukocoria is the most common presenting feature, followed by a squint which is usually convergent. Rarely, the child may present with nystagmus and defective vision. Image below showing leukocoria of left eye

Histopathology of the tumor shows small round cells with large nuclei. Microscopic features of a well-differentiated tumour include Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes (highly specific of retinoblastoma), Homer-Wright rosettes, pseudorosettes, and fleurettes formation. Areas of necrosis and calcification can also be seen.

The histopathological image of retinoblastoma is shown below.

Treatment typically involves chemotherapy plus focal therapy. The commonly used three-drug regimen is the CVE regimen consisting of Vincristine, Carboplatin, and Etoposide. Focal therapy includes cryotherapy, laser photocoagulation, thermotherapy, plaque radiotherapy, and external beam radiotherapy.
Enucleation is done when
  • The tumor involves more than half of the retina
  • The optic nerve is involved
  • Glaucoma is present and the anterior chamber is involved

Other options:

Option B - Medulloblastoma is a malignant embryonal tumor of childhood that occurs exclusively in the cerebellum. Patients usually present with headaches, ataxia, and signs of brainstem involvement.

Histologically, the tumor is very densely cellular. Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and elongated or crescent-shaped hyperchromatic nuclei. Tumor cells form Homer Wright rosettes. They express neuronal markers such as synaptophysin.

Option C - Rhabdomyosarcoma is the most common soft tissue sarcoma of childhood. The child usually presents with rapidly progressive unilateral proptosis. There are 4 subtypes - embryonal, alveolar, botyroid, and pleomorphic. Cells show light microscopic features of striated muscle differentiation. Immunohistochemistry is positive for desmin.

Option D - Astrocytoma of the retina and optic nerve head is rare. It is usually asymptomatic and is most frequently seen in tuberous sclerosis. Fundus examination reveals a yellowish or white plaque, nodule, or mulberry-like lesion. These lesions are semitransparent peripherally and calcified centrally.

Image showing calcified astrocytoma:

Related Pearl: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

  • Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas
  • Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 
  • Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions
  • Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 

 

Medulloblastoma:

  • Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells
  • Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped
  • Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil

 

Ependymoma:

  • Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 
  • Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel

 

Oligodendroglioma:

  • Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 
  • Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries

 

Retinoblastoma: 

  • Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen
  • Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center
  • Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.

questions.text: An industrial worker was admitted to the hospital after an eye injury sustained while cutting stone with a hammer and iron chisel. A foreign body was suspected to be impacted in his eye. Which of the following is the best investigation for foreign body localization?
questions.solution:
CT scan is the best method for intraocular foreign body (IOFB) localization.

The foreign bodies most likely to penetrate and be retained in the eye are minute chips of iron or steel. While chipping stone with an iron chisel, the chip of the iron chisel is more likely to enter the eye than the stone. A foreign body entering the eye may cause damage by:

  • mechanical effects
  • introduction of infection
  • reacting with the intraocular tissues

Anteroposterior and lateral view X-rays are recommended for locating an IOFB as most foreign bodies are radio-opaque. Ultrasonographic localization can tell the position of even non-radiopaque foreign bodies. CT scan is the best method of IOFB localization.

MRI is contraindicated for metallic IOFB.MRI can be detrimental for a patient with a history of an intraocular foreign body (IOFB) after cutting stone with a hammer and chisel. It can cause further damage by producing movements of the foreign body if it is magnetic. The use of MRI is contraindicated for metallic (iron) foreign bodies and is not recommended as a screening procedure.

Management: A foreign body should always be removed unless:

  • it is inert and probably sterile
  • little damage has been done to vision 
  • the process of removal will destroy sight

 

Siderosis bulbi refers to the ocular degenerative changes produced by an iron foreign body. It usually occurs 2 months to 2 years after the injury. This condition is due to the electrolytic dissociation of the metal by an intrinsic resting current in the eye which disseminates the metal, combining it with cellular proteins and cause atrophy.

Clinical features:

  • Iris: first stained greenish and later turns reddish-brown, causing heterochromia iridis.
  • Pupil: iron deposition in sphincter leads to mydriasis.
  • Lens: iron deposition in a radial fashion on the anterior capsule of the lens, leading to anterior capsular cataract.
  • Retina: pigmentary retinopathy; followed by atrophy of the retina and retinal pigmentary epithelium.
  • Secondary open-angle Glaucoma: due to damage to the trabecular meshwork.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best line of treatment in a 3-year-old child presenting with a recent onset of 15-degree accommodative esotropia?
questions.solution:
The best line of treatment in accommodative esotropia is a refractive correction.

Esotropia for distance is corrected by the treatment of hypermetropia: convex glasses

Esotropia for near is corrected by +3DS lens.

Algorithm for the management of accommodative esotropia is as follows:

  • R: Refractive correction: Glasses/Miotics
  • O: Orthoptics/Occlusion: for amblyopia
  • O: Operative correction: for non-accommodative component
  • P: Prism correction: for remaining error

questions.text: A contact lens user presents with the following clinical picture. He had watering, redness, and foreign body sensation in the eye for the past 2 months. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical history of watering, redness, foreign body sensation in a contact lens user, along with the image showing giant papillae in the conjunctiva suggests a probable diagnosis of giant papillary conjunctivitis.

Giant papillary conjunctivitis is a severe form of mechanically induced papillary conjunctivitis. It is most commonly associated with contact lens wear. It can also be associated with ocular prostheses, exposed sutures, and scleral buckles.

The patients usually present with redness, foreign body sensation, increased mucus production, itching, blurring, and loss of contact lens tolerance. On examination, giant papillae are seen on the upper tarsal conjunctiva with hyperemia. Focal apical ulceration and whitish scarring may develop on larger papillae.

Papillae are reddish, flat-topped raised areas that give a red and velvety appearance to the tarsal conjunctiva These are the hyperplasia of the normal vascular system with glomerulus-like bunches of capillaries growing into the epithelium.

The image below shows papillae in the tarsal conjunctiva.

Treatment includes removing the offending cause. Mast cell stabilizers such as sodium cromoglycate, and drugs like azelastine and olopatadine which have combined antihistamine and mast cell stabilizing effects are effective. Steroids can be used for resistant cases.

Other options:

Option A - Trachoma is caused by chlamydia trachomatis. In acute trachoma, sago grain follicles are characteristically seen as shown below. 

Option B - Follicular conjunctivitis has follicles which are greyish-white raised areas seen on fornices and palpebral conjunctiva. These are formed due to localized aggregations of lymphocytes in the sub-epithelial adenoid layer. It is most commonly caused by herpes and adenoviruses. The image is shown below.

Option D - In spring catarrh (vernal catarrh), cobblestone appearance is a papillary reaction in the palpebral conjunctiva, ropy discharge, and Maxwell–Lyon sign are present. Horner-Tranta’s spots which are discrete whitish raised dots along the limbus can also be seen. It is more common during summer.

Image showing Horner-Tranta’s spots.

Related Pearl: WHO Programme to Control Trachoma: SAFE Strategy

  • S—Surgery: Trichiasis and entropion correction surgery → 3° prevention.
  • A—Antibiotics: Oral azithromycin, topical 1% tetracycline, topical 1% azithromycin → 2° prevention
  • F—Facial hygiene → 1° prevention.
  • E—Environmental cleanliness → primordial prevention

Strategy depends on the prevalence of trachoma follicle in children (1–9 yrs)

  • Prevalence >10% → SAFE
  • 5 to 10% → FE
  • < 5% → NO intervention

questions.text: A worried mother brought her son for vision examination when she noticed him reading a book too closely. She says he also narrows his eyes while watching television. Examination revealed myopia. Which of the following lens should be prescribed to correct this child's vision?
questions.solution:
Concave lenses are used for correcting myopic errors.

Myopia, also known as 'short sight', is that dioptric condition of the eye in which, with the accommodation at rest, incident parallel rays come to a focus anterior to the light-sensitive layer of the retina. 

Other options:

Convex lenses are used in the correction of hypermetropic eye and presbyopic eye.

Cylindrical lenses are used in the correction of astigmatism.

Related Pearl: Causes of Myopia

Myopia

Etiology

Axial myopia

(Most common)

Increase in the anteroposterior length of the eyeball.

Curvatural myopia

Increased curvature of the cornea, lens, or both

Positional myopia

Anterior placement of the crystalline lens in the eye

Index myopia

Increase in the refractive index of crystalline lens

Nocturnal myopia

Due to spherical aberration and accomodation

Related Pearl: Surgical correction of Myopia

Cornea-based procedures

Lens-based procedures

Laser-based:

Photorefractive keratectomy (PRK)

Laser in-situ keratomileusis (LASIK)(Most common)

 

  1. Refractive lens exchange
  2. Phakic intraocular lens
  3. Clear lens extraction

Refractive lenticule extraction (ReLEx) (or)

Small incision lenticule extraction (SMILE)

Intracorneal ring segment (ICRS) implantation

Orthokeratology

Radial keratotomy (obsolete)

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the casualty with a sudden loss of vision and painful ocular movements. On examination in the affected eye , a relative afferent pupillary defect is seen , however the optic disc was normal. Visual field testing was done which revealed central scotoma in the same eye. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a sudden painful loss of vision in the absence of fundoscopic changes, RAPD and central scotoma is suggestive of optic neuritis, specifically retrobulbar neuritis. 

There are 3 types of optic neuritis: papillitis, neuroretinitis, and retrobulbar neuritis. The common causes of retrobulbar neuritis include demyelinating disorders such as multiple sclerosis (MS) and neuromyelitis optica (NMO or Devic's disease).

Clinically, optic neuritis is characterized by sudden, progressive visual loss.  Ocular movements are painful in retrobulbar neuritis and painless in papillitis and neuroretinitis. Glowing sensations known as phosphenes may be induced with sound or movement. Color vision may also be impaired. 

On examination, Marcus Gunn pupil or relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) is usually noted due to asymmetric involvement. The most common visual field defect is a central or centrocecal scotoma. 

Type Retrobulbar neuritis Papillitis Neuroretinitis
Pathology Inflammation of the optic nerve behind the disc Inflammation of the optic nerve head  Inflammation of the optic nerve head and the macula
Fundus appearance Optic disc appears normal

Hyperemia and oedema of the optic disc with or without peri-papillary flame-shaped hemorrhages

 Macular star (due to exudates that form around macula)
Prevalence Most common in adults

Most common in children

 Least common type
Associated conditions Strong association with demyelinating disorders like MS, NMO

Weak association with demyelinating disorders

 Cat-scratch disease, Lyme disease, Syphilis etc.

 

The image below shows papillitis.

 

The image below shows macular star appearance in neuroretinitis.

Causes of RAPD:

  • Severe retinal disease (e.g., central retinal artery occlusion, extensive retinal detachment)
  • Maculopathy (macular degeneration )
  • Optic nerve lesions (e.g., optic neuritis, retrobulbar neuritis in multiple sclerosis , anterior ischemic optic neuropathy , glaucoma)
  • Optic tract lesions (e.g., infarction)

Causes of central/centrocaecal scotoma

  • Optic neuritis
  • Compressive lesion eg. Pituitary adenoma
  • Optic neuropathy due to
  • Poor nutrition
  • Tobacco
  • Alcohol
  • Drug- induced optic neuropathy
  •  
  • Toxin- induced optic neuropathy
  • Hereditary optic atrophy
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Leukemia

questions.text: A patient from a North-Eastern state was diagnosed to have an infection with P. falciparum malaria. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate treatment for Plasmodium falciparum infection in North-Eastern states is artemether (20 mg) plus lumefantrine (120 mg).

As per National Vector Borne Disease Control Program (NVBDCP): 

  • Plasmodium malariae: treat as Plasmodium falciparum
  • Plasmodium ovale: treat as Plasmodium vivax
  • Severe and complicated malaria

            -Intial parenteral treatment x 24-48 hr:  quinine/artemether/artesunate/arteether

            -Oral treatment after 48 hrs-after parenteral quinine: quinine + doxycyclinex 7 days or quinine + clindamycin x 7 days (pregnancy and chidren<8yrs)

            -After parenteral artimisin derivates: in NE states: ACT -AL X 3 days+primaquine (day2) , in other states:ACT-SPX 3 days+primaquine (day 2) 

  • Chemoprophylaxis

                       Short-term, less than or equal to 6 weeks: Doxycycline OD (start one day before travel and continue for 4 weeks after return)

                        Long-term, more than 6 weeks: mefloquine weekly (start 2 weeks before travel and 4 weeks after return).

Related Pearl: Treatment of Malaria
