questions.text: The number of maternal deaths per 100,000 live births is called ___.
questions.solution:
Maternal mortality ratio is defined as the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 live births during a given time period.

Other options:

Infant mortality rate (IMR) is defined as the ratio of infant deaths registered in a given year to the total number of live births in the same year.

Maternal mortality rate is the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 women of reproductive age in a given time period.

Related Pearl: Maternal Mortality Ratio

Maternal death is defined as the death of a woman while pregnant or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy, irrespective of the duration and site of pregnancy, from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management but not from accidental or incidental causes.

  • Maternal mortality ratio is the number of maternal deaths in a given period per 100,000 live births during the same period.
  • MMR = Number of maternal deaths in a period x 100,000 (or 1000)/Number of live births in the same period
  • Main global causes of maternal deaths are severe bleeding, indirect causes (anemia, malaria, heart diseases), infections, unsafe abortions, eclampsia, obstructed labor and other direct causes like ectopic pregnancy, anesthesia related complications, etc.
  • In India, the most common causes of maternal deaths are hemorrhage (leading cause), sepsis, obstructed labor, hypertensive disorders, etc.

Related Pearl: Perinatal Mortality Rate

  • The term ‘perinatal mortality’ includes both late fetal death (stillbirths) and early neonatal deaths.
  • Babies chosen for inclusion in perinatal statistics should be above a minimum birth weight (1000g at birth). If the birth weight is not available, a gestation period of at least 28 weeks should be used (as the weight at 28 weeks corresponds to 1000g). If both are not available, then crown to heel length of at least 35cm should be used.
  • Generally, the PMR = Late fetal deaths and early neonatal deaths weighing over 1000g at birth x 1000/Total births(live+dead) weighing over 1000g at birth.
  • The PMR is the yard-stick of obstetric and pediatric care before and around the time of birth.
  • The PMR of India (2016) is 24 per 1000 births.
  • The main causes of perinatal mortality are intrauterine and birth asphyxia, low birth weight, birth trauma, and intrauterine/neonatal infections.

Please note that the actual perinatal period commences from the 22nd week of life, but at that time the fetus weighs only about 500g.

Therefore, only for statistical calculations and international comparisons, to calculate the perinatal mortality rate, the period from the 28th week of life is taken, as then the baby weighs about 1000g. As mentioned, babies included in the perinatal statistics must weigh above 1000g.

questions.text: Which of the following indicators is the best to know the overall burden of disease?
questions.solution:
DALY is the best measure of the overall disease burden in a defined population and the effectiveness of interventions.

DALY (Disability Adjusted Life Years):

  • It can measure both mortality and disability together.
  • One DALY can be considered a lost year of a "healthy" life.
  • The sum of these DALYs across the population, or the burden of disease, can be thought of as a measurement of the gap between current health status and an ideal health situation where the entire population lives to an advanced age, free of disease and disability.

DALYs for a disease or health condition are calculated as the sum of the Years of Life Lost (YLL) due to premature mortality in the population and the Years Lost due to Disability (YLD) for people living with the health condition or its consequences:

Calculation

DALY = YLL + YLD

The YLL basically corresponds to the number of deaths multiplied by the standard life expectancy at the age at which death occurs. The basic formula for YLL (without yet including other social preferences discussed below), is the following for a given cause, age, and sex:

YLL = N x L

where:

  • N = number of deaths
  • L = standard life expectancy at the age of death in years

Prevalence YLD

YLD = P x DW

where:

  • P = number of prevalent cases
  • DW = disability weight

Other options:

Option A: QALY is a disability rate indicator. It is based on the number of years that would be added to life due to medical intervention. A utility value of 1.0 is given for each year of perfect health and 0 for death. It is the measure of the disease burden which includes both quality and quantity of life.

Option B: HALE (health adjusted life expectancy) is an indicator that estimates the number of years a newborn is expected to live in full health based on the current rates of ill health and mortality. HALE is calculated using the life expectancy at birth with an adjustment for time spent in poor health. It was known as DALE (disability-adjusted life expectancy) previously.

Option D: DFLE (disability-free life expectancy) is an indicator that estimates the average number of years an individual is expected to live free of disability if the current pattern of mortality and disability continues to apply. It is also known as active life expectancy and is calculated by:

DFLE = Life expectancy - Duration of disability

Related Pearl: QALY vs. DALY

QALY and DALY are disability indicators used as measures of health in a population.

QALY

Quality Adjusted Life Years

DALY

Disability Adjusted Life Years

 

Measures quality of life in health gain

 

Measures health loss in quality of life

 

Indicator of cost effectiveness of intervention

 

Indicator of overall burden of disease in a population

 

Expressed as 1 or 0 where,

1 = Perfect health

0 = Death

 

 

Expressed as 0 or 1 where,

0 = Perfect health

1 = Death

questions.text: A study to determine the association between maternal smoking during pregnancy and low birth weight is being carried out. It involves obtaining smoking histories from pregnant women during their antenatal visits and then subsequently assessing the birth weight of their babies soon after delivery. What type of study is this?
questions.solution:
The study of choice is a prospective cohort study.
A prospective cohort study is a study in which the outcome has not yet occurred at the time that the investigations begin. They begin in the present and continue into the future.
 
This study is a prospective cohort study because the subjects (pregnant women) were categorized on the basis of exposure or lack of exposure to a risk factor -smoking during pregnancy. They were followed to determine if the outcome- the low birth weight of the babies occurred or not.
The design of a prospective cohort is shown below.
A retrospective cohort study is when both the exposure and outcome have occurred before the investigations and study is undertaken. An example would be if the charts in a hospital from the previous year were reviewed, and mothers classified as smokers or nonsmokers based on records. The records are then followed through time and then the birth weight of the children in both groups are compared. It is also called a historical cohort study, a prospective study in retrospect, or a non-concurrent prospective study.
 
In a case-control study of the same, low birth weight infants would be selected as the cases and normal birth weight babies as the controls. The frequency of maternal smoking would then be compared in the two groups.
 
In cross-sectional studies, exposure and outcome are measured at the same point in time.

Related Pearl: Cohort Study

  • A cohort study progresses from cause to effect, as exposure has occured but not disease.
  • It is also known as forward-looking study, incidence study, prospective study, and longitudinal study.
  • Design of a Cohort Study
    • Types
      • Prospective cohort studies (concurrent cohort studies)
      • Retrospective cohort studies (historical cohort study)
      • Combination cohort studies
    • Steps
      • Selection of study subjects
      • Obtaining data on exposure
      • Selection of comparison groups
      • Follow-up
      • Analysis in terms of incidence rates and estimation of risk
    • Advantages and disadvantages

Advantages

Disadvantages

Incidence can be calculated.

Several possible outcomes related to exposure can be studied at same time.

Provides direct estimate of relative risk

Calculation of dose-response ratio

Minimization of certain biases

Cannot be used for uncommon diseases

Uses a large population

Takes a long time to complete

Many common administrative problems

Attrition is high.

Selection of subjects is difficult.

Dynamism of diagnostics is difficult to incorporate.

Tend to be expensive.

Tends to alter behaviour of subjects: Hawthorne effect.

Ethical problems

questions.text: During your rural posting, you are asked to educate a small, uneducated village about the importance of routine antenatal care for pregnant mothers. You want to deliver some statistical data to emphasize its importance. Which of the following is the best way to do so?
questions.solution:
Pictogram is the best method of presenting data among people, who cannot understand orthodox charts. 

In this method, small pictures or symbols are used to present the data. Fractions of the picture are used to represent numbers smaller than the value of a whole symbol. Basically, pictograms are a form of bar charts.

Other options

Option B- Line diagrams are mainly used to show the trend of events in a given period of time. For example trend of dengue cases in Asia during 2018-21.

Option C- Histogram is a pictorial diagram of a frequency distribution that consists of a series of blocks. The frequencies are given along the vertical axis and class intervals on the horizontal axis. The area of each block obtained is proportional to frequency. 

Option D- Frequency polygon is the diagrammatical representation of frequency distribution obtained by joining the midpoints of the histogram blocks.

Related Pearl: Graphical Representation of Data

1. Histogram

  • A histogram, by definition, is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.
  • The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.
  • The following is a histogram of cholesterol levels from the Framingham Heart Study.

2. Bar Chart

  • It is also called a bar graph.
  • It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data as they are not quantitative and usually qualitative.
  • The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups.
  • Bar graphs can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.

3. Pie Charts

  • Pie charts are also used for nominal or ordinal data.
  • The categorical data are represented as segments of a circle.

4. Frequency polygons

  • Frequency polygons are used for mainly ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

5. Ogive

  • A frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve which is called an ogive. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.

6. Line chart

  • It is also called a line diagram or line graph.
  • Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

questions.text: For a population of 10,000, what does a sex ratio of more than 1000 mean?
questions.solution:
For a population of 10000, if the sex ratio is more than 1000, it means males are less than 5000 i.e., less than half the population.

The sex ratio refers to the number of females per 1000 males. An ideal sex ratio would be 1000 which indicates the population comprises an equal number of males and females.

Sex ratio >1000 indicates that there are more females than males in a population. Sex ratio <1000 indicates that there are fewer females compared to males in the population.

Related Pearl: Sex Ratio

  • It is the number of females per 1000 males.
  • According to a census in 2011, the sex ratio in India was 940 females per 1000 males.
  • Kerala currently holds a favorable sex ratio with values of 1084 females per 1000 men.
  • The sex composition of the population is affected by the differentials in mortality conditions of males and females, sex-selective migration and the sex ratio at birth.
  • A very low sex ratio indicates male-child favoritism.

questions.text: A couple has given birth to their first child. Based on the nuclear family cycle,  which phase is the family entering into?
questions.solution:
The phase of a nuclear family cycle from the birth of their first child to the birth of their last child is called extension.

Related Pearl: The Family as a Social Organization

  • A family is a group of biologically related individuals living together under the same roof and eating from a common kitchen.
  • It is the most primary and basic unit of all societies.
  • The basic and arbitrary model of a family cycle has six phases:

 

Phase

Beginning

End

1

Formation

Marriage

Birth of 1st child

2

Extension

Birth of 1st child

Birth of last child

3

Complete extension

Birth of last child

1st child leaves home

4

Contraction

1st child leaves home

Last child leaves parental home

5

Completed contraction

Last child leaves parental home

Death of 1st spouse

6

Dissolution

Death of 1st spouse

Death of survivor
  • Types of families:
    • A nuclear family or elementary family consists of only the married couple and their offspring while they are dependants.
    • The term new family is applied when nuclear families are younger than 10 years and consist of parents and children.
    • A joint family or extended family consists of a number of married couples and their children who live together in the same household with usually the men being related by blood. All property in joint families is held in common with the family income going into a common pocket. A senior male member is usually the head of the family who makes decisions.
    • A three generation family is one where there are representatives from three different generations in one house.
    • A communal family is one in which all the members play a part in its management.
  • Functions of the family:
    • Residence (patrilocal and matrilocal)
    • Division of labour
    • Reproduction and raising children
    • Socialization and social care
    • Economic functions
  • Problems families are those that lag behind the rest of the community in terms of standard and quality of life of its members.
  • Broken families are those in which the parental or family system has been disrupted by separation, divorce or death.

questions.text: When quarantine was introduced in the 14th century for plague, how many days were people who were suspected to have the infection quarantined for?
questions.solution:
In the 14th century, quarantine was used for plague and the suspects were quarantined for 40 days.

The idea of quarantine when it was initially introduced was that, the disease would remain dormant in the quarantine period and die out. But the 40 day period caused inconveniences and was based on a lack of scientific knowledge regarding the causation and spread of the disease. 

Quarantine is the restriction on the movement of people, animals, and goods that may have been exposed to a communicable disease. It is intended to prevent the spread of communicable diseases. 

Quarantine is distinct from medical isolation, in which those confirmed to be infected with a communicable disease are isolated from the healthy population.  

It is a primary level of prevention and falls under specific protection measures. The various types of quarantine are:

  • Absolute - Complete limitation of movement
  • Modified - Selective partial limitation of movement
  • Segregation - Observation of a group of persons in a population after separation

Note:

With respect to the COVID-19 pandemic, home quarantine is advised when a person comes in contact with a COVID-19 positive patient.

questions.text: In a normal curve, what is the percentage of the distribution that falls within one standard deviation of the mean?
questions.solution:
According to the empirical rule of normal distributions, 68% of the distribution falls within 1 standard deviation of the mean.

In a normal curve, the area on either side of the mean will include :

Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within ±1 standard deviations of the mean.

Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within ±2 standard deviations of the mean.

Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within ±3 standard deviations of the mean.

Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

  • Normal distribution is the most widely used continuous distribution.
  • It is also called bell curve (bell shaped) or Gaussian distribution after a mathematician named Karl Friedrich Gauss.
  • The following is an image of three different types of normal distributions.
  • Normal distributions are defined by two parameters: the mean and the standard deviation.
  • The mean, median and mode are all equal in a normal distribution.
  • All normal distributions are symmetric and have bell-shaped density curves with a single peak.
  • Exactly half of the values are to the left of the centre and the other half to the right.
  • The total area under the curve is 1.
  • The density of a normal distribution is more around the centre and less around the tails.
  • There is no skew in the curve.
  • Looking at the figure below, we can understand the empirical rule of a normal distribution which states that:
    • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 1 SD).
    • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 2 SD).
    • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 3 SD).
  • Many data like blood pressure, heights, IQ scores, etc. form a normal distribution.
  • A standard normal distribution is a normal distribution with a mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1.
